courses.subject: ASST
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the themes and intellectual approaches that comprise the broad field of Asian Studies.  It is an interdisciplinary course that aims to introduce students primarily to the study of the peoples and cultures of East and South Asia.

courses.subject: ASST
courses.description: This course explores the representations of culture, politics, society, and identity in a variety of films and other visual culture media (such as television, social media, literature, and music) from Asia.  During the semester students will engage a breadth of media representations pertaining to Asia to study the development of different Asian civilizations in a historical and transnational context on some of the key issues facing these countries today.

courses.subject: ASST
courses.description: This course explores special themes in Asian Studies, including, but not limited to, literary, cinematic, social, political, economic, cultural, and international relations topics. Students analyze the course's theme on Asia in transnational contexts through class readings, presentations, discussions, and class assignments. Students will conduct research and write a final paper and/or create a final project on an approved Asian Studies topic, following the guidelines established by the instructor. This class is taught by regular or visiting faculty. Topics change each term. May be repeated for credit as topic changes.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Two hours lecture and one two-hour laboratory period per week.  A study of biology spanning contemporary issues in the biological sciences from the cellular and molecular to the ecosystem and biosphere levels of biological organization.  Laboratory experiences are conducted in the biology computer lab.  Designed for non-science majors.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Microbiology Gen Transfer NSC

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: One laboratory period per week.  This laboratory is an inquiry-based course that provides an introduction to investigative techniques in biology and skills required for the analysis and presentation of scientific findings.  Throughout the course there will be a focus on molecules through cells.  This course is required for each student declaring a major interest in Biology and/or with an interest in pre-health programs.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: A senior high school course in Biology or Chemistry. This course is an introduction to the inner workings of cells, with the theme of examining the common biomolecular foundation of all living things. Topics include the basic principles of evolution, the molecular organization, structure, and function of cells, the cell cycle (including mitosis and meiosis), gene expression, metabolism, and Mendelian and molecular genetics. This course is designed for science majors.
courses.prerequisites: A senior high school course in Biology or Chemistry

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: One laboratory period per week.  This is a laboratory introduction to the diversity, evolution, anatomy and physiology of eukaryotic organism (protists, fungi, plants, and animals.)  Topics covered include the principles of evolution by natural selection , population genetics, speciation, anatomy, physiology, and taxonomy.  This course is required for each student declaring a major in Biology and/or with an interest in pre-health programs.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: A senior high school course in Biology or Chemistry. This course is an introduction to the workings of organisms (prokaryotes, protists, fungi, plants, and animals), with the theme of exploring the variety of solutions that have arisen in living things in response to the challenges of life. Topics include the principles of evolution, population genetics, speciation, biological systematics, reproduction, homeostasis, and physiology across various branches of life. This course is designed for science majors.
courses.prerequisites: A senior high school course in Biology or Chemistry

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This is an inquiry-based laboratory course that provides an introduction to investigative techniques in biology and practice in the analysis and presentation of scientific findings. The topics investigated span the full scope of biology, from molecules and cells through populations and ecosystems. The course consists of one credit hour of lecture and two credit hours of lab, and is designed for science majors.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Special problems.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: limited to students who are majoring in Nursing (not Nursing pre-majors) and students whose first major is Kinesiology (not Kinesiology minors). Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. The structure and function of cells and tissues; the architectural plan of the human body, and the integumentary, skeletal, muscular systems and nervous systems. This course is intended for science majors that require Anatomy and Physiology as a prerequisite for application to graduate or professional school as well as Nursing, Health and Fitness, and Athletic Training majors.
courses.prerequisites: limited to students who are majoring in Nursing (not Nursing pre-majors) and students whose first major is Kinesiology (not Kinesiology minors)

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Prerequisite: BIOL 20204 with a grade of C or better and permission of instructor. Structure and function of the nervous, circulatory, digestive, respiratory, excretory, reproductive and endocrine systems of the human body. This course is intended for science majors that require Anatomy and Physiology as a prerequisite for application to graduate or professional school as well as Nursing, Nutrition, Health and Fitness and Athletic Training majors.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 20204 with a grade of C or better and permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Microorganisms and the manner in which they affect health; characteristics, growth requirements, methods of transfer, and reactions of the body toward invading organisms and the principles underlying immunity. This course is intended for Nursing, Nutrition, and Secondary Education Life Science majors or majors that require microbiology for professional school.  This course cannot be applied to the Biology major and is not intended for pre-health students applying to professional schools such as medical, dental, physician's assistant or veterinary schools.  Credit will not be given for both BIOL 20234 and 30304.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 10501, 10503, 10511 and 10513.  Examination of the biological basis behind a variety of current issues in public health.  Critical analysis of these issues through lectures, class discussion and debate.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 10503 and 10513. Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  Study of the diversity of invertebrate animals including their morphology, physiology, development, evolution, and natural history.  Emphasis on their role as model organisms in biological and biomedical research.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 10503 and 10513

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: 10501, 10503, 10511, 10513. The economic importance of plants for food, building, material, clothing, fuel, medicine, oils, dyes and other products.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 10503, 10513 and 10501 or 10523.  A general course in microbiology intended for Biology majors or pre-health students applying to professional schools such as medical, dental, physician's assistant or veterinary schools. Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  Credit will not be given for both BIOL 20234 and 30304.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  BIOL 30403 or ENSC 30133
Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  An Interdisciplinary exploration of the biology, chemistry, geology, physics, and human use of the ocean and its resources.  This course is recommended for students with a major interest in the life and earth sciences.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 30324)
courses.prerequisites:
BIOL 30403 or ENSC 30133
Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 10503, and 10513. Three hours lecture per week. Principles and concepts of ecology and their application to environmental biology and conservation.  Topics will include human impacts on the environment and current issues of importance to global sustainability.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture and one laboratory per week.  This course focuses on the form and functional significance of anatomical structures in vertebrate animals.  The objectives of the course are to introduce students to the anatomical evidence for evolution and to help students develop an understanding of vertebrate anatomy that will prepare them for graduate or medical gross anatomy courses.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: Biol 10513 and Biol 10511 or 10523.  Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of structure and functional significance of tissues, organs, and organ systems in the human body, with attention to selected disease processes.  Students will develop an understanding of human anatomy that will prepare them for graduate or medical gross anatomy courses. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 30414 and either 20204 or 20214.
courses.prerequisites: Biol 10513 and Biol 10511 or 10523

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: PSYC 10213, 10514, 10524 or its equivalent. Study of the nervous system, action systems, and sensory systems as background for the physiological bases of discrimination, motivation, emotions, and learning. (Crosslisted as BIOL/PSYC 30463.)
courses.prerequisites: PSYC 10213, 10514, 10524 or its equivalent

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of the morphology, life history, physiology, ecology, evolution and socio-economic aspects of plants.  Coverage includes the cyanobacteria, fungi and algae.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL  10503, and 10513; CHEM 10113. Three hours lecture per week. Basic structure and function of plant and animal cells; molecular genetics of cells and organisms; mechanisms governing cell reproduction and differentiation.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Two hours lecture and one laboratory per week.  A survey of some of the diverse habitats and lifeforms on earth, with an emphasis on North American ecosystems.  Arctic tundra, forests, swamps, aquatic habitats, deserts, and mountains are considered in light of the unique adaptations required for associated fauna and flora, and especially, some of the challenges they face in the modern world.  The course is designed for students with broad interests in science, especially environmental science and education majors and is also suitable for non-science majors.  This course cannot be applied toward the biology course requirements for a biology major.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Two hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Characteristics of the major groups and families of flowering plants. Basic history and general principles of taxonomy and fundamental concepts of phylogeny and plant evolution. Identification of plants represented in the local flora.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 10503 or 10513.  In this course, human ecto- and endo-parasites will be discussed along with their associated diseases.  Students will gain knowledge of parasite life cycle, molecular mechanisms of entry, mechanisms of immune evasion and current and potential therapies.  Public health strategies for control and elimination of parasitic diseases will also be explored.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: PHYS 20484 or 20485 or 10164.  An introduction to image formation for molecular and medical applications.  This course covers the fundamentals of optic, x-ray and MRI, image creation, detectors, basics of image processing, quantitative analysis and a variety of applications in biophysics and in medicine.  Includes off-campus lab work.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/PHYS 30843.)

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Honors Seminar.  May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course is only for students in the Honors College.  Field and laboratory research experiences for advanced students.  Nine clock hours per week are required for a total of 135 hours.  The results will be written in the form of a senior honors research thesis to be presented to the Honors College.  A student may receive credit for this course only one time.  Credit will not be given for both 40033 and 40803 for the same project.  This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. degree in biology.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 30603. This 0.5-hour course focuses on a variety of topics relevant to students who are interested in careers in the health professions. The course may be repeated.  At most one hour may be applied to the Biology major or minor.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 30603.  Three hours lecture per week. Survey course in the study of mechanisms of inheritance with particular emphasis on molecular genetics.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 30603.  A one credit hour laboratory course (one laboratory period a week). After completion of the course the student will develop an understanding of concepts and techniques currently in use in molecular biology and biotech research laboratories and will learn how to use basic bioinformatics tools to analyze DNA sequences.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL  30603; CHEM 30123 (or concurrent enrollment) or permission of instructor.  A study of the molecular mechanisms of human disease with an emphasis on the role of intracellular signaling events on the manifestation of disease, gene expression/regulation, the structure and function of macromolecules, cell growth and differentiation, and biotechnology based solutions to treatment.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL  30603; CHEM 30123 (or concurrent enrollment) or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Two three-hour laboratories plus associated lectures each week.  Prerequisites: BIOL 30603 and 40123.  Experiments that illustrate the basic principles of transmission and molecular genetics.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 and 40123

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 10501, 10503, 10511, 10513, 30403, and 30603.  Genetics plays an important and diverse role in the preservation of biological diversity.  This course consists of two one-hour lectures and one three-hour laboratory each week and covers genetic theory and methods that are utilized in modern conservation efforts.  Laboratory exercises focus on 1) the practical aspects of DNA extraction methods, molecular markers, PCR, sequencing, and capillary electrophoresis, and 2) analyzing the resulting genetic data.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology.  This course consists of two one-hour lectures and one three-hour laboratory each week.  Lectures cover the evolution, anatomy and physiology, life histories, behaviors, and conservation of birds.  The laboratory portion of the course includes identifying birds with molecular methods and field trips to identify common species of Texas birds.  Five Saturday morning field trips are required.
courses.prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: six semester hours in Biology.  Two hour lectures and two hours of laboratory per week.  This course introduces advanced undergraduate students to mammals.  Lectures will examine the major topics of mammalian biology, including the evolutionary history, classification, adaptations, ecology, and natural history of mammals.  Field techniques for the study of mammalian biodiversity and abundance will also be covered in this course.  Field trips will be required. (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 40173.)
courses.prerequisites: six semester hours in Biology

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 30603 and BIOL 30403 OR Instructor Permission.  This course critically engages the historical eugenics movement in the United States and its precursors in the broader Western scientific tradition with attention to current and future advancements in biology. Students will employ a combination of scientific and ethical analysis to interrogate social/political and biological claims about inherited traits and race that were dominant in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.  Students will further analyze contemporary advancements in biology while applying ethical lessons from the past.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 and BIOL 30403 OR Instructor Permission

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 30603 or permission of the instructor. Two hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of basic tissues of the vertebrate body and how they differentiate.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 30603 or permission of the instructor.  Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week.  An introduction to developmental biology and embryology.  Modern molecular and genetic techniques will be combined with classic anatomical embryology.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  C- or better in BIOL 30603, or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. The immune system; characteristics of antigens; antibodies and their reactions; cellular and humoral aspects of immunity; immune disorders.
courses.prerequisites: C- or better in BIOL 30603, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description:
Prerequisite: BIOL 30304 or BIOL 40254.  This lecture-based course features current research in Immunology that focuses on how manipulations of the innate or adaptive immune system can modulate disease states. This includes how microbes overcome immune defenses, failures in immune system function and
how the immune system can be therapeutically modified to treat disease.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30304 or BIOL 40254

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite:  BIOL 40123.  This class will consist of two hours of lecture and one laboratory per week.  The course focuses on the ways in which information at the genome level has become integral to Biology.  The labs are designed to give students hands on experience analyzing genomic data to ask and answer specific questions.  Contemporary primary literature will be discussed.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 40123

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.  This course focuses on advanced topics in medical microbiology including disease mechanisms of major human pathogens, the host response, and antibiotic development and resistance.  Scientific approaches used to investigate these topics are emphasized through reading and discussion of the primary literature.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of the instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture per week. An ecological approach to the study of the distribution of plant and animal communities.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve.  Students serve as laboratory instructors of one section per week in introductory-level biology courses.  Students receive 1 credit for serving as laboratory instructors for one section per week and one additional credit for each three hours of additional duties per week including laboratory staff meetings.  May be repeated once.
courses.prerequisites: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve.  Students receive one credit hour for serving as laboratory instructors of one section per week and one additional credit hour for each three hours of additional duties per week including laboratory staff meetings.  This course is intended only for undergraduate Teaching Assistants in courses above the freshman level.  Not to exceed six hours credit on the major and eight hours credit total.
courses.prerequisites: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Six semester hours in Biology.  Two hour lectures and a three hour laboratory each week.  This discussion-oriented course introduces advanced undergraduate students to the general principles of wildlife ecology and how those principles can be applied to wildlife management and conservation.  The objectives of this course are 1) to provide an introduction to the major concepts of Wildlife Ecology and Management and 2) to allow you to learn the application of the scientific method to ecological problems.  Laboratory exercises are required.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 40353)
courses.prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 30603 with a C or better or permission of instructor. Basic functions of the major mammalian systems will be studied in terms of physical and chemical principles and system interactions.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 with a C or better or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 40403.  This course focuses on the underlying principles of toxicology including dose-response curves, routes of contaminant exposure, contaminant fate in the environment and in organisms, and xenobiotic metabolism.  Discussions of both historical and contemporary primary literature will be used to explore the specific effects of contaminants on various physiological systems.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 40403

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 40403.  Two hours of lecture and one laboratory period per week.  The course will focus on the structure and function of hormone signaling systems in vertebrate organisms.  Contemporary primary literature will be discussed and the laboratory will expose students to the experimental design and methods utilized in modern endocrinology research.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 40403

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  CHEM 30123 and C- or better in BIOL 30603, or permission of instructor.  Three hours of lecture per week.  The structures, properties, and functions of biological molecules (proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates), with emphasis on analysis techniques and relation to physiology.
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 30123 and C- or better in BIOL 30603, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 40513 or BIOL/CHEM 50133 or equivalent course.  Two hours of lecture and two hours of laboratory per week.  Students will learn structural biology techniques important for designing pharmaceuticals and design a drug to their favorite protein target.  Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 40523.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 40513 or BIOL/CHEM 50133 or equivalent course

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 30603 or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture per week.  Survey of viruses, molecular biology of virus life cycles, viral pathogenesis and gene therapy using viral vectors.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  6 credit hours of Biology or equivalent.  The course examines selected cultures in an international setting.  Social and scientific factors are related to health beliefs and practices and health care delivery systems of the country visited and examined.  Critical analysis of selected topics will be accomplished.  Usually taught in summer abroad program.  (Cross-listed as BIOL 40703/NURS 30063/ENSC 40203)
courses.prerequisites: 6 credit hours of Biology or equivalent

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor.  This one to four credit, lecture-only course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Field and laboratory research experiences for advanced students. Nine clock hours per week are required total 135 hours per semester. Upon completion of an independent research project, the results will be written in a format suitable for publication in the scientific literature. A student may receive credit for this course only one time. Credit will not be given for both BIOL 40803 and BIOL 40003 for the same project.  This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. degree in biology.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor.  This one to four credit lecture with integrated lab course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors. This course can be repeated. This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. or B.A. degree in biology.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor.  This one or two credit lab course will deal with a specific topic in Biology that is appropriate for Biology majors. This course can be repeated. This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. or B.A. degree in biology.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and BIOL 30603, or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Field and laboratory problems for advanced students. Three clock hours per week of laboratory and/or field work are required for each semester hour of credit, for up to three semester hours credit in any given semester.  This course can be repeated or taken in combination with 40803 or 40033.  This course will count as one laboratory course towards the B.S. degree in biology.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Instructor permission.  This course focuses on current scientific research in biology including discussions of primary literature and presentations of active research projects.  This course may be repeated.  May only be taken P/NC.  This course cannot be applied toward the course requirements for the biology major or minor.
courses.prerequisites: Instructor permission

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Senior standing as a biology major with an Intent to Graduate on file in the Dean's Office.  One class session.  Graduating seniors enrolled in this course will complete the exit exam required of biology majors.  May only be taken P/NC.
courses.prerequisites: Senior standing as a biology major with an Intent to Graduate on file in the Dean's Office

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor. Concepts, principles, and mechanisms of the function of terrestrial ecosystems, including ecophysiology of component species, nutrient cycling, energy flow, ecosystem stability and global ecology.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and 30603 or permission of instructor.  Two hours lecture and two hours of computer lab per week.  Students will gain knowledge and understanding of how statistical methods are applied to biological research.  The course will emphasize hypothesis testing, study design, and the concepts, application, and interpretation of statistical results.  Basic probability theory, parametric statistics, correlation, regression, analysis of variance, and non-parametric statistics will be introduced.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30403 and 30603 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: CHEM 30133 and 40123 or permission of instructor. Three hours lecture per week. A general survey of structure and function of biologically important compounds with methods of analysis. (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50133.)
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 30133 and 40123 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL/CHEM 50133. Biosynthesis, replication of DNA, synthesis and processing of RNA and proteins, and special topics e.g. brain and muscle functions, hormones and signal transduction, cancer, development, etc.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50143.)
courses.prerequisites: BIOL/CHEM 50133

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture per week.  Prerequisites: BIOL/CHEM 50143, or permission of instructor.  Molecular mechanism of drug actions, and methods of drug design, discovery and development.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50153.)
courses.prerequisites: BIOL/CHEM 50143, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: BIOL 10501, 10503 10511 and 10513. Concepts and principles of organic evolution.  Topics include natural selection, adaptation, quantitative genetics, sexual selection, kin selection, life history characters, speciation, and phylogeny.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 30603 and 40123 with a C or better in each or permission of instructor.  This course introduces the theory of evolution and its real-world applications to the practice of medicine.  Concepts of survival and reproduction defining evolutionary fitness, co-evolution, competition, natural selection, bottleneck effects, adaptation and exaptation will be introduced and applied in the context of managing and treating infectious and non-infectious human and animal diseases.  These concepts will be applied beyond individual-level medicine to population-level public health.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 and 40123 with a C or better in each or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: permission of instructor.  The current literature associated with the neurobiology of aging, modern research techniques and recent developments in neuroscience and aging research are discussed.  This is a participation course in which advanced undergraduate and graduate students will present manuscripts, explain research hypotheses and methodologies and explain results.  Open discussion of these papers will include faculty from Biology and Psychology.  Topics presented will differ by semester.  The course may be repeated three times (taken a maximum of four semesters in all.)  (Crosslisted as BIOL/PSYC 50401.)
courses.prerequisites: permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Graduate or senior standing or permission of instructor. The fundamentals of functional neuroanatomy and neurophysiology with an emphasis on experimental and theoretical analysis of the basic brain behavior relationships.   (Crosslisted as BIOL/PSYC 50463.)
courses.prerequisites: Graduate or senior standing or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Two four-hour laboratory periods per week. Prerequisite: CHEM 50143 or concurrent registration.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/CHEM 50502)
courses.prerequisites: CHEM 50143 or concurrent registration

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor. Two hours lecture and one laboratory period per week. Study of the physical, chemical and biological factors affecting the ecology of lakes, ponds and streams.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30403 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Six semester hours in Biology; travel costs are exclusive of tuition.   This course provides an introduction to the marine animals, plants, and ecosystems of the New World tropics.  Lecture topics will include tropical oceanography and ecosystems, evolutionary patterns in the tropics, island biogeography, and conservation of marine biodiversity.  The field experience will expose students to coastal marine ecosystems (coral reefs, mangroves, beaches, and seagrass beds).  Two hours lecture per week, one week of field work in the tropics.
courses.prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology; travel costs are exclusive of tuition

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Two hours lecture per week, one week of field work in the tropics and a terminal project. Prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology; travel costs are exclusive of tuition; permission of instructors. This course provides an introduction to the animals, plants, and ecosystems of the New World tropics.  Lecture topics will include tropical climate and ecosystems, evolutionary patterns in the tropics, and conservation of biodiversity.  The field experience will expose students to coastal ecosystems (coral reefs, mangroves, and seagrass beds) as well as tropical, lowland rainforest.
courses.prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology; travel costs are exclusive of tuition; permission of instructors

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: 1. The primary goal is to acquaint the student with the preparation and presentation (oral and/or written) of scientific information from the biological literature. May be repeated for credit with different topics to a maximum of 3 times (one semester hour per topic). 2. Acquainting the student with the preparation and presentation (oral and/or written) of scientific information from the biological literature. May be repeated for credit with different topics to a maximum of 3 times. (One semester hour per topic.)

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three to six semester hours.  Seminar in methods of teaching Biology and supervised classroom and laboratory teaching.  Open to students who are Teaching Assistants or National Science Foundation Trainees.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: The goal of this course is to acquaint the student with the organization, preparation and effective delivery of scientific seminars.  ALL BIOLOGY GRADUATE STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO TAKE THIS COURSE.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This 0.5 credit hour seminar course will introduce biology graduate students to a wide range of research areas within the biological sciences, aid students in developing scientific communication skills, and provide student an opportunity to network with scientists from diverse fields in biology. This course may be repeated up to two, four and eight times by MA, MS, and PhD students, respectively. P/NC

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Graduate Standing.  One semester hour.  The purpose of this course is to provide pedagogical training to Biology graduate students.  In this course, different educational theories and classroom issues will be discussed.  Students will gain experience in classroom management, teaching styles, assessment, exam composition, and creating a syllabus.
courses.prerequisites: Graduate Standing

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Graduate Standing.  One semester hour.  The course focuses on building the professional skills necessary for graduate students to succeed, both at TCU and in their future careers.  Topics covered include CV/resume preparation, professional communication and networking, conduct at scientific meetings, ethics, time management, and jobs in biology.
courses.prerequisites: Graduate Standing

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 50133, 50143 or permission of instructor. Cell ultrastructure with special emphasis on preparative techniques useful in the study of functional morphology of cells.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 50133, 50143 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of oral and written scientific communication through the development and presentation of an oral seminar and written proposal over their research goals and objectives.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: BIOL 10504, 10514, 30403, and 30603 or permission of instructor.  Genetics plays an important and diverse role in the preservation of biological diversity.  This course consists of two one-hour lectures and one three-hour laboratory each week and covers genetic theory and methods that are utilized in modern conservation efforts.  Laboratory exercises focus on 1) the practical aspects of DNA extraction methods, molecular markers, PCR, sequencing, and capillary electrophoresis, and 2) analyzing the resulting genetic data.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 10504, 10514, 30403, and 30603 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: This course consists of two one-hour lectures and one three-hour laboratory each week.  Lectures cover the evolution, anatomy and physiology, life histories, behaviors and conservation of birds.  The laboratory portion of the course includes identifying birds with molecular methods and field trips to identify common species of Texas birds.  Five Saturday morning field trips are required.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology.  Two hours of lecture and two hours of laboratory per week.  This course introduces graduate students to mammals.  Lectures will examine the major topics of mammalian biologyk including the evolutionary history, classification, adaptations, ecology, and natural history of mammals.  Field techniques for the study of mammalian biodiversity and abundance will also be covered in this course.  Field trips will be required.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 60173.)
courses.prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Graduate Standing and permission of instructor.  The primary goal of this course is to provide students with hands-on training relevant to various aspects of biological research.  Topics to vary, but may include specific bench-top or field techniques, the use of specialized statistical programs or approaches, or advanced methods of scientific communication.  May be taken for 1-3 credit hours, depending on the topic.  May be repeated for credit up to a total of 6 credit hours.
courses.prerequisites: Graduate Standing and permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture and one lab period per week.  Mechanisms of developmental biology.  Molecular, genetic, cellular, and morphological processes behind development.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture per week. Prerequisite: BIOL 30303 20233, and 40253 or permission of instructor. Immunobiology and immunochemistry of the immune response, especially cell mediated reactions. Current literature, techniques and clinical applications.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30303 20233, and 40253 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 30304 or BIOL 40254 or permission of the instructor. This lecture-based course features current research in Immunology that focuses on how manipulations of the innate or adaptive immune system can modulate disease states.  This includes how microbes overcome immune defenses, failures in immune system function and how the immune system can be therapeutically modified to treat disease.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30304 or BIOL 40254 or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Permission of instructor.  May be taken for 1-6 credit hours per semester.  A minimum of 9 hours of BIOL 60320 Graduate Research is required for the Ph.D.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology.  Two hour lectures and a three hour laboratory each week.  This discussion-oriented course introduces graduate students to the general principles of wildlife ecology and how those principles can be applied to wildlife management and conservation.  The objectives of this course are 1) to provide an introduction to the major concepts of Wildlife Ecology and Management and 2) to allow you to learn the application of the scientific method to ecological problems.  Laboratory exercises are required.  (Crosslisted as BIOL/ENSC 60353)
courses.prerequisites: Six semester hours in Biology

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  This course focuses on advanced topics in medical microbiology including disease mechanisms of major human pathogens, the host response, and antibiotic development and resistance.  Scientific approaches used to investigate these topics are emphasized.  This course includes reading and discussion of the primary literature.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: Six hours of biochemistry or permission of instructor. Fundamental properties of viruses and contribution of viral studies to molecular biology.
courses.prerequisites: Six hours of biochemistry or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 60111 and permission of instruction.  Three semester hours.  The purpose of this course is to provide advanced pedagogical training to Biology graduate students.  In this course, different educational theories and classroom issues will be discussed, practiced, and observed.  Students will gain experience in classroom management, teaching styles, assessment, exam composition, and creating a syllabus.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 60111 and permission of instruction

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours lecture per week.  Prerequisites: BIOL 30303, 40123, and 50133 or permission of instructor.  Examination of research literature dealing with selected topics in genetics.  Topics in molecular genetics are most common.  May be repeated for credit one time with different topic.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30303, 40123, and 50133 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Three hours of lecture per week. Basic functions of the major mammalian systems will be studied in terms of physical and chemical principles and system interactions.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 60001 or permission of instructor.  The primary goal is to acquaint the student with areas of study in the biological sciences not covered in detail in other courses.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 60001 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Selected when enrolling only for non-thesis examination or preparation for the examination.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Limit 3 hours unless approved by graduate committee or department chair.  Each of the assigned projects requires a minimum of 50 clock hours of field, laboratory or library work for each semester hour of credit.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: A minimum of 3 hours of BIOL 70980 Thesis is required.

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisite: BIOL 70980 and admission to candidacy.  A minimum of 3 hours of BIOL 70990 Thesis is required.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 70980 and admission to candidacy

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 60703, admission to candidacy in Ph.D., and permission of departmental chair.  Supervised curriculum development including but not limited to preparation and delivery of lectures, leading classroom discussions, and student assessment.  This course is only offered P/NC.  ALL BIOLOGY PH.D. STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO TAKE THIS COURSE.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 60703, admission to candidacy in Ph

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Admission to Ph.D. candidacy and permission of instructor.  A minimum of 6 hours of BIOL 90980 Dissertation is required.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Ph

courses.subject: BIOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Six hours of BIOL 90980 and permission of instructor.  A minimum of 6 hours of BIOL 90990 Dissertation is required.
courses.prerequisites: Six hours of BIOL 90980 and permission of instructor

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: This course assists first year students in developing an understanding of the vocational and theological vision of the curriculum they are entering to prepare for ministerial leadership.  The course initiates a process of integration of learning across the curriculum which is marked by increasing signs of competency in four areas: constructive theological analysis and capacities for articulating this analysis; knowledge and skills for engaging the social and religious diversity God created within the human family; knowledge and skills for effective, ethical, and wise ministerial leadership; and growing knowledge and skills for the work of advocacy for God's justice and love for all creation.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: Prerequisites:  completion of 27 semester hours.  Theological engagement with a concrete issue of public concern, including reflection on theories of justice, and an emphasis on embodied practice.
courses.prerequisites: completion of 27 semester hours

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: The course takes leadership and cosmopolitanism as its substantial guiding concepts. Leadership is central to almost all collective social activity and therefore has been a topic for a variety of issues that has received attention in empirical studies and theoretical works offering more or less well-grounded recipes for effective leadership. The ethics of leadership is the responsibilities of leaders to promote justice, equality, peace and the conditions necessary for people to live well in communities. In this course, we will explore that constitutes cosmopolitan leadership that embodies and lives out cosmopolitan values and responsibilities in a complex and uneven world.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: The course takes leadership and cosmopolitanism as its substantial guiding concepts.  Leadership is central to almost all collective social activity and therefore has been a topic for a variety of issues that has received attention in empirical studies and theoretical works offering more or less well-grounded recipes for effective leadership.  The ethics of leadership is the responsibilities of leaders to promote justice, equality, peace and the conditions necessary for people to live well in communities.  The ultimate aim of ethical action may be called the common good of all, regardless one's gender, race/ethnicity, class, sexuality, citizenship, religion, etc.  The idea of the common good of all is, however, in serious trouble today.  The pursuit of the cosmopolitan common good in cosmopolitan leadership has not only social, political, economic, intellectual dimensions, but also religious one as well.  Cosmopolitan leader that this course pursuits is a leader who embodies and lives out cosmopolitan values and responsibilities in a complex and uneven world.  Treating people as an end rather than a means is one of hallmarks of cosmopolitan leadership, governed by the ethics of singularity.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: May be repeated for credit.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: Prerequisites: MTS students must be in next-to-last (or last) semester; other students with instructor's permission.  Ensures that students have advanced skills in research, bibliographic documentation, and writing in different genres.  Will lay a substantive foundation for the MTS final project.
courses.prerequisites: MTS students must be in next-to-last (or last) semester; other students with instructor's permission

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: The course takes leadership and cosmopolitanism as its substantial guiding concepts.  Leadership is central to almost all collective social activity and therefore has been a topic for a variety of issues that has received attention in empirical studies and theoretical works offering more or less well-grounded recipes for effective leadership.  The ethics of leadership is the responsibilities of leaders to promote justice, equality, peace and the conditions necessary for people to live well in communities.  The ultimate aim of ethical action may be called the common good of all, regardless one's gender, race/ethnicity, class, sexuality, citizenship, religion, etc.  The idea of the common good of all is, however, in serious trouble today.  The pursuit of the cosmopolitan common good in cosmopolitan leadership has not only social, political, economic, intellectual dimensions, but also religious one as well.  Cosmopolitan leader that this course pursuits is a leader who embodies and lives out cosmopolitan values and responsibilities in a complex and uneven world.  Treating people as an end rather than a means is one of hallmarks of cosmopolitan leadership, governed by the ethics of singularity.

Leadership is central to almost all collective social activity and therefore has been a topic for a variety of issues that has received attention in empirical studies and theoretical works offering more or less well-grounded recipes for effective leadership. The ethics of leadership is the responsibilities of leaders to promote justice, equality, peace and the conditions necessary for people to live well in communities. In this course, we will explore that constitutes cosmopolitan leadership that embodies and lives out cosmopolitan values and responsibilities in a complex and uneven world.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: May be repeated for credit.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: This is the required course in the Women's Studies Certificate program.  It is open to Ph.D. and Th.M. students and others on a case-by-case basis.  It aims to give graduate students from a variety of disciplines a thorough grounding in the basics of feminist theory and methodology since the early modern period.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: May be repeated for credit.

courses.subject: BRIT
courses.description: This course is an opportunity to get an edge.  Teaching is interesting, difficult, challenging, fun, exhilarating, meaningful, and most of all complex.  Join Toni Craven (Brite Divinity School) and Sherrie Reynolds (School of Education) in a seminar exploring scholarship and research about adult learning and how we might teach based on contemporary models of learning.

courses.subject: BRLB
courses.description: Prerequisite: Special permission from the Office of the Dean or Office of the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs.  Enables access to research in the Mary Couts Burnett Library for Ph.D., Th.M. or D.Min. students working on doctoral dissertations or theses.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
courses.prerequisites: Special permission from the Office of the Dean or Office of the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs

courses.subject: BRLB
courses.description: Prerequisite: Special permission from the Office of the Dean or Office of the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs.  Enables access to research in the Mary Couts Burnett Library for Ph.D., Th.M. or D.Min. students working on doctoral dissertations or theses.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
courses.prerequisites: Special permission from the Office of the Dean or Office of the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs

courses.description: Prerequisite: Special permission from the Office of the Dean or Office of the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs.  Enables access to research in the Mary Couts Burnett Library for Ph.D., Th.M. or D.Min. students working on doctoral dissertations or theses.  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
courses.prerequisites: Special permission from the Office of the Dean or Office of the Associate Dean for Academic Affairs
