courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisite:  This course is designed for students with little or no previous knowledge of the Chinese language.  It cultivates student cultural knowledge and language skills while communicating in Chinese business environments, tailoring all language training and cultural topics to that end.  The language training helps students cultivate basic language skills to interact with the Chinese people.  Cultural topics provide a framework for Western learners to develop and Eastern perspective, guiding learners to behave in a culturally appropriate manner when they communicate within Chinese business environments.
courses.prerequisites: This course is designed for students with little or no previous knowledge of the Chinese language

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Chinese Calligraphy is designed for students who are interested in Chinese culture, philosophy, and art.  Students will practice and acquire basic calligraphy strokes, radicals and characters by using traditional Chinese calligraphy brushes.  Students will also learn the meaning and philosophy behind each Chinese character.  Prior knowledge in Chinese language and culture is not required.

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: This is an introductory Chinese course for students with no or little prior experience in standard Mandarin.  It provides students a solid training in all four skills -- listening, speaking, reading and writing, with emphasis on practicing pronunciations and building vocabulary, as well as acquiring fundamental grammatical structures.  In addition, Chinese cultures will be briefly taught throughout the class.  No prerequisite.

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisite: CHIN 10153 with a C- or better.  This course continually covers basic Mandarin Chinese to students who have already taken a semester in Chinese.  It continues strengthening integrated training in all four skills -- listening, speaking, reading and writing, but more efforts will be given to spoken and reading practicing.  In addition, Chinese cultures will be briefly noted throughout the class.
courses.prerequisites: CHIN 10153 with a C- or better

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisite: CHIN 10163 with a C- or above, or approval of instructor.  CHIN 20053 will develop listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills at the intermediate level.  Working with familiar topics, students will learn to comprehend short paragraph-level utterances; interact effectively in a variety of straightforward, concrete conversational situations; and read short paragraphs and write short, well-focused descriptive or narrative works.
courses.prerequisites: CHIN 10163 with a C- or above, or approval of instructor

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisite: CHIN 20053 with a grade of C- or better, or approval of the instructor.  CHIN 20063 will develop speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills at the intermediate-mid level.  Students will learn to understand paragraph-level utterances on familiar topics; speak with confidence in everyday interactions; read paragraphs (in characters) on learned or familiar topics; handle practical writing tasks (in characters) as short letters and memos that relate to personal and learned topics.
courses.prerequisites: CHIN 20053 with a grade of C- or better, or approval of the instructor

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisites: CHIN 20063 with a grade of C- or better, or permission.  CHIN 30053 will develop students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills at the intermediate-high level.  Upon the completion of this course, students should have acquired the following abilities: 1) Listening: can understand interpersonal conversations on practical and social topics; follow presentation on social topics or topics of personal interest and individual relevance; 2) Speaking: can engage in conversations on topics of personal interest and individual relevance and present ideas and opinions with a level of clarity and precision that native speakers can understand; 3) Reading: can comprehend text materials on non-specialized topics with the help of dictionaries; 4) Writing: can produce most kinds of informal correspondence; can present ideas and opinions at paragraph level with a level of clarity and precision that native speakers can understand.
courses.prerequisites: CHIN 20063 with a grade of C- or better, or permission

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisite: CHIN 30053 with a grade of C- or better, or approval of the instructor.  CHIN 30063 continues to develop speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills at the intermediate-high level.  Upon the completion of this course, students should have acquired the following abilities: 1) Listening: can understand interpersonal conversations on practical and social topics with ease; can follow presentations on social topics or topics of personal interest and individual relevance; 2) Speaking: can engage in conversations on topics of personal interest and individual relevance; can present ideas and opinions with a level of clarity and precision that native speakers can easily understand; 3) Reading: can comprehend text materials on non-specialized topics with the help of dictionaries; can appreciate the differences between formal and informal styles; can extrapolate meanings from context; 4) Writing: can produce most kinds of informal correspondence; can present ideas and opinions in well-connected paragraphs with a level of clarity an precision that native speakers can easily understand.
courses.prerequisites: CHIN 30053 with a grade of C- or better, or approval of the instructor

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisite:  A C- or better in CHIN 30063, or permission of instructor.  The course develops students' critical thinking about Chinese cultural phenomena by watching and discussing Chinese movies.  It provides students with an opportunity to rethink the similarities and differences between Chinese and American cultures reflected in Chinese movies.  The course will be conducted in Chinese through lectures and guided discussions of designated topics.
courses.prerequisites: A C- or better in CHIN 30063, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: This course provides an overview of Chinese culture and civilization.  Major topics such as the Chinese language, history, philosophy, religion, literature and the arts, as well as contemporary issues, will be studied.  The course encourages students to become maximally involved in class discussions about topics assigned or lectured.  No prerequisite is required.  This course is taught in English.

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisites: CHIN 20063 with a grade of C- or better.  This course is designed to move students forward in their Chinese language proficiency and intercultural competence, with particular emphasis on the use of Chinese in the workplace.  It provides students with practice in using Chinese as a foreign language to explore Chinese culture in the context of working settings.
courses.prerequisites: CHIN 20063 with a grade of C- or better

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisites: permission of instructor.  Opportunity for independent study in Chinese language or culture.  Topic and credit hours to be determined at time of registration
courses.prerequisites: permission of instructor

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: CHIN
courses.description: Prerequisites:  CHIN 30053, 30063, 30073, or 30133 with a grade of C- or better.  In this course, students will use Chinese to explore various contemporary scenes of Chinese society.  The scenes represent the domains of Chinese popular culture, social change, cultural tradition, and politics.  The topics include online dating, brand-name fever, television dramas, modern views of marriage, population change, Chinese food culture, Confucianism in modern China, and democracy.
courses.prerequisites: CHIN 30053, 30063, 30073, or 30133 with a grade of C- or better

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: An exploration of issues and doctrines that animate Christian life.  Topics include the sources and goals of theology, as well as basic questions about major doctrines.  Discussions, lectures, and course assignments identify and critically engage both patterns of faith and practice that persists over time, and theological priorities from specific cultural and historical contexts.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: A critical examination of the phenomenon of militarization and the various ways that Christian communities understand the use of national power.  Seminar participants will explore frameworks for constructing theologies that publicly address the effects of militarization on topics such as politics, economics, education, gender, and race.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Masters prerequisite: CHTH 60003 or equivalent.  An introduction to theological methods and language and to the central teachings of the Christian faith.  Attention is given to both doctrinal development and major contemporary theologians and theological movements.  Covers the doctrines of Christology, Pneumatology, Theological Anthropology, Ecclesiology, and Eschatology.
courses.prerequisites: CHTH 60003 or equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Masters prerequisite: CHET 60013, CHTH 60003, or equivalent. This course will review the historical development of the Black Theology movement.  Through a close reading of early texts of the movement and a review of the social context within which it arose, the seminar participants will be invited to a full engagement with this theological tradition.  It will be our purpose to identify not only the discrete contours of the movement, but also to identify its place in late twentieth century theological discourse.
courses.prerequisites: CHET 60013, CHTH 60003, or equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: This course is to explore the intellectual and historical background of postcolonial discourse and to examine the ways in which theologians address issues of postcolonialism and the theological issues in their thinking.  By the end of this course, the students will normally understand different approaches to issues of postcolonialism, be able to investigate conceptions of theological issues in postcolonialism, and understand how religion and its theological discourse are implicated in geopolitical and cultural strategies of postcolonialism.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Cosmopolitan discourse has recently reemerged, especially in the areas of political and social philosophies, which seeks global justice and solidarities in an era of neo-empire, globalization, and identity politics.  This course takes cosmopolitan ethos primarily from Greek philosophy, St. Paul, Immanuel Kant, Hannah Arendt, and Jacques Derrida as significant theological, philosophical grounds for global justice and human rights, and planetary hospitality and solidarity.  This course thoroughly examines significant issues in cosmopolitan discourse such as its philosophical and theological grounds, major characteristics, various types and views, theopolitical implication and application, justice, hospitality, neighbor-love, and solidarity.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Jacques Derrida (1930-2004) was one of the few thinkers, in the latter half of the twentieth century, who profoundly and radically transformed our understanding of writing, reading, con/texts and textuality.  The scope of Derrida's thinking is incomprehensible.  As a person of prayers and tears, Derrida was a prominent philosopher-theologian/theologian-philosopher who never kept his political and ethical passion separate from the uninterrupted theological, philosophical reflections.  Derrida audaciously fought against all form of apartheid and exclusion, wherever they took place; and passionately and consistently spoke out for justice, compassion, and hospitality.  This curse examines several theopolitical issues in Derrida's thinking such as deconstruction, justice, religion, hospitality, cosmopolitanism, and forgiveness.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Feminist theological discourse emerged in the 1960s as an aspect of Second Wave feminism, bringing gender issues to the attention of Christian communities and theological education.  This course will give attention to the major themes and intersections of how feminism has addressed the institutions of the Christian religion and re/constructed theological discourses and practices in more egalitarian and just ways.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Love in various forms is as old as humankind. However, love has never been as socially, politically, existentially, philosophically, and theologically decisive as it is in contemporary societies. Love becomes significant sources of the creative human power, and of the meaning of life. The increasing significance of love in various sectors of human life is a crucial theme for philosophical and theological reflections and for theorizations of contemporary societies. In this course, we will explore philosophical and theological approaches to love as discourse and practice.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: An exploration of Christian theology with special reference to the faith statements, confessions, and contemporary writings of Baptist traditions.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: An investigation of spiritual themes in the literary works of such writers as C.S. Lewis, Nikos Kazantzakis or others.  (May be repeated for credit under different topics for up to 9 credit hours.) See SPIR 70213.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Postmodernism has been exerting considerable influence upon contemporary theology.  The questions that this course will address are: How do we tell the Christian story in a postmodern, pluralistic world?  How do we theologically address the postmodern world?  How do we do postmodern theology?  This course is for students to explore the philosophical and intellectual background of postmodernism, to articulate a critical perspective on postmodernism, and to examine the ways in which theologians address issues of postmodernism and the theological issues in their thinking.

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: May be repeated for credit under different topics. (1-3 semester hours)

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisite: one 60000-level CHTH course or the equivalent.  An introduction to the philosophy of religion by way of a survey of the main types of thought which have had a vital influence on Christian thought.
courses.prerequisites: one 60000-level CHTH course or the equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisites: one 60000-level Christian Theology course or equivalent.  The constructive interpretation of theology; the dynamics of Christian faith and the basic unity of its theological affirmations.
courses.prerequisites: one 60000-level Christian Theology course or equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisite: one 60000-level Christian Theology or Church History course or the equivalent. An examination of the key issues in the development of Christian doctrine: Trinity, Christology, Sin and Grace, Sacraments, Justification and Sanctification, Encounter with the Modern World.
courses.prerequisites: one 60000-level Christian Theology or Church History course or the equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisite: one 60000-level Christian Theology course or the equivalent. Current movements, areas of controversy and fresh thinking in the life and thought of the church.
courses.prerequisites: one 60000-level Christian Theology course or the equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisite: one 60000-level Christian Theology course or the equivalent.  A systematic study of a major Christian theologian, such as Augustine, Calvin, Kierkegaard, Barth, Tillich, or the Niebuhrs.  (May be repeated for credit under different topics for up to 9 credit hours.)
courses.prerequisites: one 60000-level Christian Theology course or the equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisites: HOML 65003 and CHTH 60003 or equivalent.  This course examines both the theology of preaching and theology for preaching by engaging selected theologians and their sermons.  Students will prepare, preach, and reflect upon the theology in sermons.  Offered as CHTH 75113 and HOML 75023.
courses.prerequisites: HOML 65003 and CHTH 60003 or equivalent

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admittance to the M.T.S. degree program.  An independent research study course, taken in the final semester in program, that integrates material covered in earlier coursework, and produces a final paper, normally 20-30 pages in length.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the M

courses.subject: CHTH
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admittance to the M.T.S. degree program.  An independent research study course, taken in the final semester in program, that integrates material covered in earlier coursework and produces a final paper, normally 20-30 pages in length.

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Transfer work with TCUCC credit.

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: This course focuses on how we can develop technological solutions to problems by applying the scientific method to the study of major technological accidents and failures.  The lecture material will be augmented by laboratory experiences where the student will be able to experiment with some common everyday complex systems and study their failures under carefully controlled conditions.

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Topics of current interest.  May be repeated for credit when the topic changes. (1-3 semester hours)

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites: Junior standing or consent of instructor.  This course examines the cultural, social, ethical, and legal implications of the transforming power of the explosive growth of data and the technologies involved in producing, storing, utilizing, and communicating that data.  The associated distinctions of age, gender, ethnicity, and class along with their impact on the propensity to access and utilize the products created from various technologies will be explored as well.  These technological products include but are not limited to online/offline computer games, blogs, wikis, instant messaging, text messaging, as well as web sites for online dating and social networking.
courses.prerequisites: Junior standing or consent of instructor

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 10403 or 10503; all with C- or better.  This course will cover the installation, management, and maintenance of Unix/Linux operating systems.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 10403 or 10503; all with C- or better

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites: CITE 30103 with C- or better.  The topics of this course include advanced study of installing, configuring, and managing net-work based services and applications.
courses.prerequisites: CITE 30103 with C- or better

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COSC 20203.  Fundamental principles of interface design and scripting languages.  Topics include user interface evaluation and basic development, scripting language programming (e.g. Python), and the study of existing programs written in selected languages.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20203

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 30603.  Introduction to the database administration in both small and large-scale database operations.  Course focuses on the setup, analysis and maintenance of relational databases used in modern applications.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30603

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 30603 with C- or better.  This course will provide an overview of the current full stack web technologies. The students will learn both client-side and server-side technologies to create a functional dynamic web application. The course will include a detailed introduction to HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and HTTP followed byin-depth coverage of server-side programming and database connectivity. Popular web frameworks will also be included. Projects will be required that demonstrate the student's understanding of these technologies.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30603 with C- or better

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites: MATH 10524 and a course in statistics (either MATH 10043 or MATH 30853 or MATH 30803) additionally either COSC 30603 or ENGR 20613 is required.  The principles and practice of Operations Research Methods as a tool for decision-making are studied.  In particular, the course focuses on deterministic mathematical programming techniques such as linear programming (the Simplex Method, concepts of duality and sensitivity analysis), network optimization (transportation and assignments problems), and dynamic, and integer programming.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 10524 and a course in statistics (either MATH 10043 or MATH 30853 or MATH 30803) additionally either COSC 30603 or ENGR 20613 is required

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 30203 and MATH 20123.  Introduction to the design and operation of hardware systems that include embedded microcontrollers and/or microprocessors, and the programming techniques required to control hardware systems.  After providing an overview of analog and digital circuit theory, the course focuses on the design and operation of the interfaces between the controller(s)/processor(s) and the rest of the hardware.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30203 and MATH 20123

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites: Sophomore standing, 2.5 GPA in major, and approval of department chair.  Practical experience in computer and information science.  Must include a minimum of 90 work hours for each credit hour in approved practical experience situation.  This course may only be taken pass/no credit and may be repeated for a total of at most 3 credit hours.  Open to CITE and COSC majors only. (1-3 hours.)
courses.prerequisites: Sophomore standing, 2

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Credit for, or concurrent enrollment in COSC 30603.  This course presents an introduction to the issues involved in managing projects that are technology-based.  Principles of project development, trade-off issues through the project life-cycle, and professional ethics will be covered.  Team projects are included.
courses.prerequisites: Credit for, or concurrent enrollment in COSC 30603

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor.  Advanced topics of current interest.  Students will study current literature.  May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of the instructor

courses.subject: CITE
courses.description: Prerequisite: CITE 40643.  Senior computer information technology majors are required to demonstrate their mastery of several computer science and information technology topics and their ability to communicate the results of their efforts to others.  They are required to identify and analyze a computer development task, develop and implement a workable solution for its development, and then document the results of their efforts.
courses.prerequisites: CITE 40643

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: General Transfer Credit-OCO credit.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: In this course, students will learn communication skills, such as how to construct and deliver messages, listen actively, and communicate ethically; emphasis will be on developing public speaking skills.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Examines the science and art of effective speaking in public and private contexts.  Students will understand basic concepts and theory related to public address and will develop skills in effective group communication and oratory.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Transfer work.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Consideration of effective speech communication strategies in interpersonal situations. Practice in the development of appropriate communication skills in face-to-face interactions.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM 10123 or 10133.  This course will study elements of performance theory and techniques.  Students will analyze and interpret academic texts, current events, and various styles of literature to formulate an argument in a performance.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Applies communication theory and practice to a broad range of communication phenomena in intrapersonal, interpersonal and public communication settings.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, by permission of department.  Offered as an honors tutorial and to selected majors who are not honors candidates.  Study of current issues in Speech Communication and related fields with opportunity for development of an area of specialization.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, by permission of department

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Instructor permission required and restricted to recognized members of the TCU Forensic Team.  Participation credit for members of the competitive forensics team.  Course members will practice and engage in intercollegiate competition in public address, oral interpretation, and debate.  Repeatable a maximum of 8 times.  A maximum total of 4 credits may be applied toward a Communication Studies major, 3 credits toward a minor.
courses.prerequisites: Instructor permission required and restricted to recognized members of the TCU Forensic Team

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or by permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133 or permission of instructor. Training in clear, logical, and persuasive communication; analysis, exposition, reasoning, and use of evidence; practice in effective delivery; classroom participation in debates.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or by permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department.  Students will investigate British origins of contemporary parliamentary debate and decision-making, will visit important sites such as the Houses of Parliament and Hyde Park Speaker's Corner, and will learn to conduct parliamentary debates and employ rules of parliamentary procedure in meetings.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113.  Participation in decision-making groups to develop skills related to effective group communication. Factors affecting group interactions are considered.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department.  Students will develop knowledge and skills necessary to facilitate conflict conversations in interpersonal and organizational settings.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department.  Applies dyadic communication principles to specialized interviewing situations. Skills development is stressed.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; Combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223.  Communication channels and networks in organizations; analysis of barriers to effective communication; solving practical communication problems; communication and dynamics in work groups.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; Combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133 or permission of instructor.  Training in speech performance and speech evaluation skills. Theory and practical experience related to the formulation, presentation, and evaluation of informative and persuasive public speeches.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20223 and COMM 30163.  Explores organizational communication within special contexts.  Included theoretical concepts applicable to conflict, culture, media, etc. Repeatable for maximum of 6 hours.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20223 and COMM 30163

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 with a C- or better.  Introduction to the reception and processing of information. Examines theory and research in areas such as attention, cognitive capacity, and attribution.  Examines the role of listening in a variety of contexts, including therapeutic communication, learning, and critical thinking.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 with a C- or better and MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better.  Introduction of the conceptual foundations of nonverbal communication.  Theoretical perspectives, research methods, and applications of nonverbal communication are also explored in a variety of contexts.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 with a C- or better and MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113. Explores interpersonal communication within special contexts. Includes theoretical concepts applicable to gender, aging, and health.  Repeatable for maximum of 6 hours.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133 and COMM 20113, and COMM 20223.  Explores theory and research related to social influence in relationships and communication processes.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133 and COMM 20113, and COMM 20223

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 and 20223 with a C- or better.  Introduces students to scientific perspectives on human emotion and examines the social, moral, and cultural dimensions of communication emotions.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 and 20223 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 and COMM 20223.  This survey course examines the influence of culture on our communicative interactions with others.  Emphasis is placed on identifying the relationship between communication and culture, developing intercultural communication competence, and understanding the elements that constitute and separate cultures.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 20113 and COMM 20223

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10113.  Examination of the relationship between gender and communication.  Critical analysis of how communication creates, maintains, and transforms views of gender in cultural, social, and historical contexts.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10113

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department. Investigate great British orators, orations, and persuasive techniques used to compel audiences at the actual sites where these famous speeches took place.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133.  The purpose of this course is to introduce students to training and development in organizational settings.  Students will learn the art and science of designing, delivering, and assessing training programs.  Emphasis will be placed on teaching communication skills to adult learners and exploring potential career opportunities in training and development.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or 10133

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better and COMM 20223 with a C- or better.  This course is an introduction to theories and research related to health communication.  We will focus on how messages from interpersonal, organizational, and mediated sources affect physical, mental, and social health and well-being.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better and COMM 20223 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only; department permission. Independent work in specially designed projects not covered by regular course offerings. (1-6 semester hours, 3 hours maximum per semester.)
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only; department permission

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only; department permission.  This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only; department permission

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10133.  Examination of the major concepts in rhetorical theory.  By studying on location, emphasis is placed on understanding the conceptions of rhetoric in antiquity, identifying how these inform historical and contemporary rhetorical acts, and evaluating the persuasive techniques used to compel audiences in a variety of social, political, and religious contexts.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10133

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123.  Explores a variety of theories and applications of persuasive communication.  Focus is on the public discourse of global issues.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only; COMM 30163, permission of instructor, and department chair.  This course not only explores the analysis, planning and execution of marketing and promotional goals, strategies and tactics for a corporate structure, its divisions and departments through research, discussion, peer and instructor evaluation and experimentation but also places students in the role of communication professionals responsible for the production of tangible solutions and content using the Bob Schieffer College of Communication and other TCU academic units as its primary clients.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only; COMM 30163, permission of instructor, and department chair

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite:  COMM majors/minors only; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better; department permission.  A research paper developing from the student's specialization in the Honor's Seminar.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better; MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better.  Seminar designed to acquaint students with the factors affecting interpersonal conflict and to provide students with appropriate communication skills necessary for successful conflict resolution and negotiation in a variety of contexts, both personal and professional.  Emphasis is on exploring practical, theoretical and critical analyses of conflict and negotiation in an active learning environment.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; complete 15 hours in Communication Studies; junior or senior standing; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better or permission of instructor. Participation in professional internship experience approved by course instructor.  Online forums and writing assignments focus on analysis of communication observations and issues in professional environments.  May be repeated up to six hours, with unique employer placements.  For BS degree, only three hours qualify for credit toward the 3-course, 40000-level departmental requirement.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; complete 15 hours in Communication Studies; junior or senior standing; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better. The development and use of communication skills to manifest positive character traits for the benefit of self, others, and society at large.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; and COMM 30163 with a C- or better.  Examines power and privilege in organizations, focusing on gender, race, class, ability, age, sexuality, and religion.  Students will develop awareness of how their background shapes communication as well as exploring strategies for increasing inclusion in organizations.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better; MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better.  Examination of contrasting models and standards of communication ethics. Students apply standards to specific problem situations in politics, advertising, writing, and interpersonal communication in making reasoned and informed personal judgments concerning the ethics of public and private communication.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better; MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better.  This course is designed to investigate the nature of family communication patterns and the extent to which different communication activities contribute to, and change, familial identity.  Students will explore complex definitions of family, family interaction from different theoretical lenses, the role of family rituals, narratives, and storytelling in constructing family identity, and the role of family power, conflict, and stress on family interaction.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better.. Understanding the role of speech communication in the leadership process. Development of practical leadership communication skills and consideration of communication behavior demonstrated by leaders.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM 30163.  This course is a seminar on the dark sides of organizational communication and behavior.  Students will examine critical perspectives in organizational communication and discuss readings and case studies in organizational ethics.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 30163

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better; MATH 10043 or INSC 20153 with a C- or better.  Explores fundamental principles of communication research.  Students will develop as critical consumers of communication research and will learn to design, conduct, analyze, and report individual research projects.  Students cannot receive credit for both COMM 30283 and COMM 40283.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better.  Explores history, theory, and research related to interpersonal uses of communication technology.  Students will critically examine current forms of mediated interpersonal communication in light of the history of communication technology.  Students cannot receive credit for both COMM 30233 and COMM 40313.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2.5 in COMM 20113 and 20223; COMM 30163 with a C- or better.  To increase understanding of the multiple ways that food communication occurs.  Students will critically analyze how food functions symbolically as a communicative practice by which we create, manage, and share meanings with others.  Emphasis on how the various relationships between communication and food negotiate our identities, cultures, and environments.  Patterns of communicative food practices--and how those are influenced by social, economic, historical, and cultural contexts--are also examined.
courses.prerequisites: COMM majors/minors only, or permission of department; COMM 10123 or COMM 10163 with a C- or better; combined GPA of 2

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: COMM 20113.  This advanced seminar is designed to provide an introduction to the various messages and message strategies that fall within the purview of the dark side of interpersonal communication.  Students will examine a variety of interpersonal communication behaviors that problematize that is considered ethical, moral, and/or functional in healthy relationships, including jealousy, envy, revenge, conversational dilemmas, fatal attractions, deception, infidelity, and abuse, among others.
courses.prerequisites: COMM 20113

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: Senior or graduate standing. Specialized work in student's area of concentration. 1-6 semester hours, 3 hours maximum per semester.
courses.prerequisites: Senior or graduate standing

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Review of advanced theoretical constructs and recent research related to interpersonal communication. Comprehension, critical evaluation and applications will be stressed.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Review and analysis of communication theory and research in instructional settings.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Explores issues of influence, compliance and resistance in interpersonal relationships from a social science perspective.  Influence reciprocity and consequences to relationships are examined as effects of everyday social interaction.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Examines communication in the context of various contemporary social issues.  Course topics may vary.  Course may be repeated for credit for up to 9 hours.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Addresses advanced concepts, issues and research methodologies applicable to communication processes in contemporary organizations.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Introduction to philosophy of graduate research; study of inferential and descriptive analysis, as well as correlational and experimental methodology and design.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Examination and evaluation of social, psychological and linguistic theory applied to human communication behavior.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Application of communication principles to organizational practice and/or research projects.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Examines current theoretical perspectives, concepts, and research methodologies applicable to communication processes in families.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Explores theory and research related to interpersonal uses of communication technology.  Students will critically examine research and theory on both early and recent forms of mediated interpersonal communication.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Reviews theory and research related to the interaction between cognitive processes such as attention, perception and memory and the processing of verbal and nonverbal messages.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor.  Opportunity for individual work in a specialized area of concentration within the Communication Studies discipline.
courses.prerequisites: Communication Studies graduate student status or by permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Advanced research on special problems in Communication Studies. Content will vary according to the needs and interests of students and faculty.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of chair.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of chair

courses.subject: COMM
courses.description: Thesis

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: College algebra or two years of high school algebra. Introduction to computers, problem solving, algorithm design, and programming techniques. Includes what a computer is and is not, problem organization, data representation, and how to utilize the computer to solve problems. Numerical and non-numerical problems are solved in a high-level programming language.
courses.prerequisites: College algebra or two years of high school algebra

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Topics may vary each time it is offered.

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: College algebra or 2 years high school algebra. Introduction to computer programming and to problem solving techniques using computer programs with applications in engineering and the physical sciences.
courses.prerequisites: College algebra or 2 years high school algebra

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: This course will introduce Python data structures and ways to manipulate data.  Students will design, implement, and test Python programs.  This course will also give the students a working knowledge of how to use Python to perform data analysis.

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 10403 with a C- or better.  A study of program design, development and programming techniques. Structured programming with problems selected from list processing, string processing, and file manipulation.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 10403 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 20203 with a C- or better. Basic concepts of data. Linear lists, strings, and arrays. Representation of trees and graphs. Storage systems and structures. Symbol tables and searching techniques, sorting techniques. Formal specification of data structures and data structures in programming languages.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20203 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Courses dealing with a particular area of investigation in computer science. The topics will be changed from semester to semester and the course may be repeated when the topic is different. (1 - 3 semester hours.)

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  CITE 30103 with a C- or better.  Study of the technology, architecture, and software used by systems of network-connected computers.  Topics include data transmission, local area network architectures, network protocols, internetworking, distributed systems, security, and network applications such as email, WWW, and FTP.  Students will develop programs that run concurrently on multiple computers.
courses.prerequisites: CITE 30103 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COSC 20803 and MATH 20123 with a C- or better in both. Essential elements of the data science lifecycle from theory to practice.  Introduces fundamental skills to prepare for advanced study in data science.  Methodologies and several open source tools used in solving data science problems are studied.  (Cross-listed as COSC/MATH 30103.)
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20803 and MATH 20123 with a C- or better in both

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 20803 and MATH 20123; both with a C- or better.  Topics include a review of machine representation of data, machine language, systems programming, memory hierarchy, linking, exceptional control flow, system-level I/O, network programming, and concurrent programming.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20803 and MATH 20123; both with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: COSC Prerequisites: COSC 20803 and MATH 20123, or, ENGR prerequisites: ENGR 30444; all with a C- or better.  Treatment of sequential and combinatorial circuits including flip-flops, multiplexers, decoders, adders, registers, counters. Design of functional components, of a computer including memory, ALU, control unit, busses. The tradeoffs of alternative architectural features such as word size, instruction sets, addressing modes.  (Crosslisted as COSC 30253/ENGR 30573.)
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20803 and MATH 20123, or, ENGR prerequisites: ENGR 30444; all with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 20803 and MATH 20123; both with C- or better.  A study and comparison of the concepts and constructs of major programming language paradigms.  Topics include programming language syntax, names, scopes, and bindings, semantic analysis, control flow, and data types. In addition, the course includes learning ANTLR to write parsers, and studying Scala, a functional programming language.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20803 and MATH 20123; both with C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 30253.  The logical organization and functional behavior of digital computers are studied.  Fundamental principles in the design of the CPU, memory, I/O devices, and bus structures are presented.  Performance enhancement topics such as caching, memory interleaving, interconnection schemes, pipelining, memory management, reduced instruction sets (RISC) and multiprocessing are discussed.  (Crosslisted as COSC 30453/ENGR 30593.)
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30253

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 20203.  An overview of the UNIX operating system focused on command-line and server interfaces.  An introduction to the C/C++ programming language, UNIX commands, shell programming, process management, memory management, I/O, network communication, and systems programming in C/C++ with low-level kernel calls.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20203

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 20803, and MATH 20123.  All prerequisites need to be C- or better. Introduction to the design, implementation, and use of relational database systems. Topics include entity-relationship modeling, relational algebra, normalization, SQL, external data structures, query optimization, non-relational models, and applications.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20803, and MATH 20123

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 20803.  Discrete event simulation programming and analysis techniques for simulation experiments.  Includes experimental sampling and model development in a special purpose simulation language.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20803

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 30203 with a C- or better. Introduction to basic data communications concepts, including hardware and software aspects of protocols, asynchronous and synchronous communication, network configurations, and error detection. This course includes the study of both local area networks and long haul networks, the 7 layer ISO network model, the architecture of networks, and network communication protocols. Local and wide area networks including the internet and world wide web will be discussed.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30203 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC/MATH 30103, MATH 30224, and prerequisite MATH 10043 or corequisite MATH 30853; all with C- or better.  Students will study the principles and practices of machine learning.  Specifically, regression and classification will be studied to obtain and analyze patterns in datasets.  To facilitate exploratory data analysis, students will also study data preprocessing techniques and data visualization practices.
courses.prerequisites: COSC/MATH 30103, MATH 30224, and prerequisite MATH 10043 or corequisite MATH 30853; all with C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 30203 or CITE 30103; all with a C- or better.  This course will cover the fundamental principles, architectures, and standards of modern wireless communications systems, as well as specific applications and uses of these systems.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30203 or CITE 30103; all with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COSC 30403 with a C- or better.  The course introduces Android app development using Kotlin.  This is a project-based course with the focus on developing simple to moderately complex Android apps.  Along the way, students will learn the important concepts of Kotlin programming as well as how to implement key Android features.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30403 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: MATH 20123, and COSC 30203 or CITE 30103; all with a C- or better.  This course will cover the fundamental principles and techniques in computer systems and network security.  Key topics include cryptographic systems, security standards, protocols, tools and applications.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 20123, and COSC 30203 or CITE 30103; all with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 30253 and a knowledge of linear algebra MATH 30224. A basic course in graphics systems. Considers the equations of lines, planes, and surfaces; hidden line algorithms; rotations, scaling, and cutaway transformations; 3-D images and the use of shading and perspective; animation; and color graphics.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30253 and a knowledge of linear algebra MATH 30224

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 30203 with a C- or better, COSC 30253 with a C- or better. Introduction to operating systems concepts, principles, and design.  Topics include: processes and threads, CPU scheduling, mutual exclusion and synchronization, deadlock, memory management, file systems, security and protection, networking, and distributed systems.  Selected existing operating systems are discussed, compared, and contrasted.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30203 with a C- or better, COSC 30253 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  CITE 30103 with a C- or better and completed at least 18 hours in Major.  An introductory course on Cloud Computing, with special emphasis on AWS Cloud Foundations curriculum.  The course will provide a detailed overview and help students get an overall understanding of cloud computing concepts.  More specifically, students will get hands-on exposure to the AWS cloud, including but not limited to the AWS core services, security, architecture, pricing, and support.
courses.prerequisites: CITE 30103 with a C- or better and completed at least 18 hours in Major

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 30253. Introduction to the design of microprocessor based digital systems including the study of processor control signals, address decoding and memory interfacing, interfacing to serial and parallel ports, A/D conversion, and interrupt processing. Features of state-of-the-art microprocessors will be discussed. Both hardware and software assignments will be required.  (Crosslisted as COSC 30353/ENGR 30583.)
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30253

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: MATH 10524 and COSC 10403 or 10503, and either COSC 20803 or ENGR 40574.  The study and practice of the principles, the algorithms and the techniques of image processing such as editing, analysis, segmentation, recognition and classification.  Students will use Java to implement and test various image processing algorithms.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 10524 and COSC 10403 or 10503, and either COSC 20803 or ENGR 40574

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description:
Prerequisite: COSC 20803, Corequisite MATH 30123; all with C- or better, and a knowledge of probability and statistics. This course covers basic approaches for designing and analyzing for a variety of problems. Algorithm design techniques such as divide-and-conquer, greedy, dynamic programming will be covered. Other topics
include worst, best, and average case analysis, graph algorithms, string matching, and complexity.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 20803, Corequisite MATH 30123; all with C- or better, and a knowledge of probability and statistics

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COSC 30403 with C- or better.  This course teaches how to write code of high quality by providing an in-depth coverage of object-oriented programming principles and techniques.  Topics include but not limited to fundamental object-oriented programming concepts, software design principles (SOLID), Gang of Four (GoF) design patterns, coding standards, refactoring.  Each topic will be explained by using diagrammatic notations Unified Modeling Language (UML) and numerous real-world code demos.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30403 with C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 40403 and MATH 20123, all with grade C- or above.  Introduction to knowledge representation and methods for intelligent search, planning, and learning. Fundamental topics include uninformed and informed search, adversarial search, constraint satisfaction problems, logical agents, knowledge representation, reinforcement learning, expert systems, and a bit of machine learning.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 40403 and MATH 20123, all with grade C- or above

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  COSC/MATH 30103, MATH 30224, either MATH 10043 or 30853 or concurrent.  All prerequisites need to be C- or better.  Introduces fundamental knowledge of deep learning algorithms, practical skills to build, train and tune a deep artificial neural network with applications such as computer vision, natural language processing, and business analytics.  Topics include but not limited to fully connected neural networks, convolutional networks, recurrent networks, generative adversarial networks.
courses.prerequisites: COSC/MATH 30103, MATH 30224, either MATH 10043 or 30853 or concurrent

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 30203, COSC 30403, and MATH 30123. Formal description of algorithmic languages, such as Pascal, and the techniques used in writing compilers for such. Topics include syntax, semantics, storage allocation, code generation, error handling and diagnostics, code optimization, etc. Includes the definition and writing of a compiler for a simple programming language.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30203, COSC 30403, and MATH 30123

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 40203.  An introduction to hardware and software topics in high performance and parallel computing.  Students will be introduced to a variety of high performance and parallel computing paradigms including message passing, threading models, and shared-memory programming techniques.  Topics include motivation and history, parallel architectures, parallel algorithm design, and parallel performance analysis.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 40203

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor.  Advanced topics of current interest in computer hardware, such as computer design, computer networks, advanced computer graphics.  Students will study current literature.  May be repeated for credit when topic changes.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. Advanced topics of current interest in computer software, such as natural language programming, advanced operating systems, advanced compiler design, file structures, advanced database. Students will study current literature. May be repeated for credit when topic changes.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 30603 or concurrent, senior standing in COSC or CITE or DASC (24 hours in the major.)  All prerequisites need to be C- or better.  Stages of the software development life cycle (requirements analysis, specification, design, implementation, testing), evolution, and quality assurance are covered. Classical and alternative process models are described. Project management issues, professional responsibilities, and ethics of the profession are discussed. This course includes team projects.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30603 or concurrent, senior standing in COSC or CITE or DASC (24 hours in the major

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 40943 with a C- or better. Senior computer science majors are required to demonstrate their mastery of several computer science topics and their ability to communicate the results of their efforts to others. They are required to identify and analyze a computer science problem, develop and implement a workable solution to the problem, and then document the results of their efforts.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 40943 with a C- or better

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisites: COSC 40603.  Languages and grammars which can be characterized in formal terms, for the purpose of constructing models for artificial (computer) languages.  Topics will include finite automata, push down automata, Turing machines, solvable and unsolvable problems, etc.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 40603

courses.subject: COSC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. (1-6 semester hours).
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Transfer work.

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Survey of disorders of articulation, language, stuttering, voice and hearing.

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: An introductory course in signing expressively and understanding basic sign language, receptively. Included is basic information on hearing loss and its effects on children and adults. Recommended for students majoring in special education and service-oriented fields as well as those who are interested in learning sign language.

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: An introduction to acoustic and physiological aspects of the speech and hearing mechanisms.

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Required of all majors and elective to others. Emphasis on speech perception and sound discrimination. Intensive work in transcription using the International Phonetic Alphabet.

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSD 10343 with a grade of C or higher or permission of instructor. Further development and refinement of receptive and expressive skills in Signed English and American Sign Language. Emphasis on vocabulary development for classroom use, ability to sign fluently, and the psycho-social aspects of deafness, including the sociolinguistics of sign language and Deaf Culture.
courses.prerequisites: COSD 10343 with a grade of C or higher or permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite:  COSD 10303 with a grade of C or better.  This course will focus on identifying the fundamental concepts related to scientific inquiry in communication sciences and disorders to allow students to become critical readers of peer-reviewed journal articles.  The course will consider identification of research literature relevant to a specific topic or disorder, basic concepts involved in the formulation of research questions and methodology, and levels of research evidence available to audiologists and speech language pathologists.
courses.prerequisites: COSD 10303 with a grade of C or better

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite:  SPPA or DHHS major or minor, or permission of instructor. Structure and function of the normal mechanisms required for speech and hearing.
courses.prerequisites: SPPA or DHHS major or minor, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Junior standing and membership in the Honors Program. Under the guidance and supervision of a faculty member, current issues in communication sciences and disorders are explored.
courses.prerequisites: Junior standing and membership in the Honors Program

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: An overview of normal acquisition and development of language in children from infancy through adolescence for non majors.

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisites:  SPPA major, COSD 10303 and 20333, with a grade of C or higher in all COSD coursework, cumulative GPA of at least 3.00, and a cumulative 3.00 GPA in COSD courses or permission of instructor. Basic principles of diagnosis and treatment for individuals with developmental or functional speech sound disorders of articulation.
courses.prerequisites: SPPA major, COSD 10303 and 20333, with a grade of C or higher in all COSD coursework, cumulative GPA of at least 3

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: SPPA or DHHS major or permission of instructor. Normal acquisition and development of language in children from infancy through adolescence.
courses.prerequisites: SPPA or DHHS major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSD 30363 with a grade of C or higher in all COSD coursework, cumulative GPA of at least 3.00, and a cumulative 3.00 GPA in COSD courses. Overview of management and rehabilitation of persons with hearing loss.   Focus on amplification, cochlear implants, assistive devices, speech training, speech reading, auditory training and language development.
courses.prerequisites: COSD 30363 with a grade of C or higher in all COSD coursework, cumulative GPA of at least 3

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. Curriculum materials and teaching methods for meeting specialized needs of DHH children, in the learning of reading and developing concepts and relationships in arithmetic and science.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSD 20503 with a grade of C or higher. Basic audiometric techniques and interpretation of audiograms as related to problems of communication of persons with hearing loss.
courses.prerequisites: COSD 20503 with a grade of C or higher

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: SPPA major or permission of instructor.  COSD 30334 with a grade of C or higher in all COSD coursework, cumulative GPA of a least 3.00, and a cumulative 3.00 GPA in COSD courses.  Introduction to the causes, characteristics, assessment and treatment of children with language disorders.
courses.prerequisites: SPPA major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Basic Sign Language or permission of the instructor.  Study of American Sign Language (ASL) including advanced study of grammatical structure and signing technique.  Introduction to deaf culture associated with the use of ASL.  Students will learn and demonstrate receptive and expressive signing skills through advanced experiential learning exercises.
courses.prerequisites: Basic Sign Language or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSD 30334 with a grade of C or higher, or permission of instructor.  This is the first of two courses devoted to the study of language development of Deaf/Hard of Hearing (DHH) students.  It will address the early intervention needs of young DHH infants and their parents as well as DDH students in lower primary grades.
courses.prerequisites: COSD 30334 with a grade of C or higher, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSD 10303, 20333, and 30333, with a grade of C or higher in all COSD coursework, cumulative GPA of at least 3.00, and a cumulative 3.00 GPA in COSD courses or permission of instructor. Principles and procedures in the assessment and treatment of communication disorders.
courses.prerequisites: COSD 10303, 20333, and 30333, with a grade of C or higher in all COSD coursework, cumulative GPA of at least 3

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. Independent study of specially designed topics not addressed in regular course offerings. 1-6 hours, 3 hours maximum per semester.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSD 30003, with a grade of C or higher, senior standing, and membership in the Honors Program. The completion of a research project related to a current issue in normal and/or disordered communication.
courses.prerequisites: COSD 30003, with a grade of C or higher, senior standing, and membership in the Honors Program

courses.subject: COSD
courses.description: Prerequisite: SPPA major.
