courses.description: General Transfer Credit-FAR credit

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major.  This introductory level course is the first in the Pilates I-IV series. Through the Pilates work, students engage in practice and analysis of the body in action, and learn to work functionally, efficiently and safely.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  Dance major and/or DANC 10211. This intermediate level course is
the second in the Pilates I-IV series. Through the Pilates work, students engage in practice and analysis of the body in action, and learn to work functionally, efficiently and safely.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and/or DANC 10211

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor.  Practical experience in all facets of dance production related to departmental presentations.  (Maximum of .5 credit hour per semester.  Course may be repeated for a maximum of 2 credit hours.)  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
courses.prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance major or permission of instructor.  This course will provide dancers with a basic understanding of music theory and structure.  Students will have practical experience working with musicians (composers and accompanists) as applied to dance.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance majors.  This course will introduce first year dance majors to specific information relevant to their development as students, dancers and artists.  Topics include:  careers in dance, health and wellness, portfolio building, audition practices, and resource gathering.
courses.prerequisites: Dance majors

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet and/or Modern Dance Technique or permission of the instructor.  This course focuses on improvisation as a dance form; a means of developing movement in the moment that fuses the role of creator and performer.  Various approaches to improvisation will be presented and explored, including improv as a tool for dance composition.  Students will acquire basic skills for critical response and analysis.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet and/or Modern Dance Technique or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: This course provides studio practice of an international dance form.  Various dance forms will be offered and will be designated with a descriptive course title. Course may be repeated for credit.

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance major.  Approaches to healthful and efficient movement through topics including structure, alignment and conditioning particularly appropriate to the aspiring professional dancer.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Beginning ballet for general students.  Introduction to theory and practice of classical ballet for general students.  This is a studio-based movement course.   (Course may be repeated for credit.)

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Introduction to the training, theory and practice of foundational modern dance and
contemporary dance forms at the beginner level. This is a studio-based movement
course. (Course may be repeated for credit.)

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: This course is the study of various Social Dance styles.  The styles offered will vary.  Classes include basic movement patterns, technique, elements of style, lead and follow (as applicable), and dance etiquette.  Course content will be drawn from ballroom or other partner dance styles including circle dances, line dances, and club dances.  Course may be repeated.

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Introduction to character dances selected from a variety of classical ballets designed to develop character dance technique and musicality.

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Historical and critical examination of dance as a fundamental human expression present across world cultures.

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance Major status or permission of instructor.  Training in the foundational technique of classical ballet.  (1.0 - 2.5 hours maximum per semester. Course may be repeated for credit.)
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major status or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance majors only or permission of instructor.  Independent project supervised by faculty. (0.5 - 3 credit hours per course.)  May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Dance majors only or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisite: Dance Major status or permission of instructor. Training, theory and
practice in foundational classical modern and/or contemporary dance forms at the
beginning level. 1 credit min to 2.5 hours maximum per semester. Course may be
repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major status or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  Dance major and/or DANC 10221. This intermediate-advanced
level course is the third in the Pilates I-IV series. Through the Pilates work, students engage in practice and analysis of the body in action, and learn to work functionally, efficiently and safely.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and/or DANC 10221

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites: Dance major and/or DANC 20211. This advanced level course is
the fourth in the Pilates I-IV series. Through the Pilates work, students engage in practice and analysis of the body in action, and learn to work functionally, efficiently and safely.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and/or DANC 20211

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: DANC 10312 or permission of instructor.  This course explores contact improvisation as a duet form grounded in the principles of weight sharing, gravity and momentum.  Dancers will work together to hone improvisational skills that include heightened awareness and partnering work that requires commitment, responsiveness, and immediacy.  May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: DANC 10312 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance major and concurrent enrollment in daily dance technique course; DANC 20100, 20200, 30100, 30200, 40100, 40200, or 40150.  This course is a performance course.  Students earn the opportunity - via audition or casting process - to perform in either a faculty or guest artist work.  Through the performance experience, students utilize dance technique and artistry developed in ballet and modern dance courses.  This course may be repeated for credit up to 2 hours, .5 credit hour per semester (1.5 hours minimum required for dance majors.)
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and concurrent enrollment in daily dance technique course; DANC 20100, 20200, 30100, 30200, 40100, 40200, or 40150

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor.  Three hours lecture/movement lab and 1 hour science lab each week. This course presents various scientific tools of movement analysis that supports and facilitates the work of dance professionals.  Emphasis will be placed on using scientific
research to develop a greater understanding of the form and function of the body in order to optimize dance-training practices.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: DANC 10312, Dance Major, and concurrent enrollment in a Ballet and/or Modern Dance technique class.  Introduction to the craft of choreography.  Students are introduced to the elements of dance movement and basic compositional theories, create choreographic studies and engage in critical analysis.
courses.prerequisites: DANC 10312, Dance Major, and concurrent enrollment in a Ballet and/or Modern Dance technique class

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor.  Dance Production is an introduction to design and production for dance.   This course provides broad exposure to design and production with emphasis on their relationship to dance performance.  It is a survey of production areas including basic visual design, scenery and costumes, lighting, sound, and video.  It also provides an introduction to the mechanics of the tools, lighting instruments, control consoles, sound systems, video projectors, and other technology used in live performance.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Placement audition and/or permission of instructor required.  Study and practice of classical ballet technique for general students at the intermediate level.  (Course may be repeated for credit.)
courses.prerequisites: Placement audition and/or permission of instructor required

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Placement audition and/or permission of instructor required. Study and practice of modern dance technique for general students at the intermediate level. (Course may be repeated for credit.)
courses.prerequisites: Placement audition and/or permission of instructor required

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Study and practice at a beginner/intermediate level of dance styles that are influend by the many roots of jazz dance. Structure of class will include warm-up, technical practice, progressions, and choreography. Course content will draw from Musical Theatre, Theatrical Jazz, Vernacular, Hip-hop, and Latin influences. Course may be repeated for credit.

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prior dance training required. Study and practice at an intermediate/advanced level of dance styles that are influenced by the many roots of jazz dance. Structure of class will include warm-up, technical practice, progressions, and choreography. Course content will draw from Musical Theatre, Theatrical Jazz, Vernacular, Hip-hop, and Latin influences. Course may be repeated for credit.

The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance Major; DANC 20100 or permission of instructor. Daily training in the contemporary practice of classical ballet at the intermediate level. (2.0 - 2.5 hours maximum per semester. Course may be repeated for credit.)

courses.description: Prerequisites: Ballet Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet Technique (DANC 30100, 40100 or 40150); or permission of instructor. This course develops the strength, technique and skill specific to pointe work at the advanced levelof technique. Repeatable for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Ballet Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet Technique (DANC 30100, 40100 or 40150); or permission of instructor

Theory, methods of teaching dance with specific focus on ballet.

courses.description: Prerequisite:  Dance Major, DANC 30111, and concurrent enrollment in DANC 30100, 40100, or 40150, or permission of instructor. Practice and performance of ballet repertoire from the Romantic, Classical, Neo-Classical, and Contemporary ballet repertoire. Repeatable for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major, DANC 30111, and concurrent enrollment in DANC 30100, 40100, or 40150, or permission of instructor

courses.description: Prerequisites:  Dance Major enrollment by permission only and concurrent enrollment in DANC 20100, 30100, 40100 or 40150; or permission of instructor.  Emphasis on partnering in classical and contemporary ballet. Course may be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major enrollment by permission only and concurrent enrollment in DANC 20100, 30100, 40100 or 40150; or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisite: Dance major status or permission by instructor. Training, theory and
practice of classical modern and/or contemporary dance forms at the intermediate
level. (1 hour minimum - 2.5 hours maximum per semester.)
courses.prerequisites: Dance major status or permission by instructor

courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance Major, DANC 20221 and permission of the instructor. This course is an advanced Pilates course and first in the Practica I-IV series. Content in Practica I-IV is progressive and moves the student toward the completion of comprehensive professional training in the Pilates system addressing skills, theory, history, teaching practice and philosophy.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major, DANC 20221 and permission of the instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 30211. This course is an advanced Pilates
course and second in the Practica I-IV series. Content in Practica I-IV is progressive and moves the student toward the completion of comprehensive professional training in the Pilates system addressing skills, theory, history, teaching practice and philosophy.

courses.description:
Prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 30200. Theory, methods and
materials of teaching dance with specific focus on modern and contemporary dance.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 30200

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 10300, or permission of instructor.  Continued practical experience in dance production leadership related to departmental presentations.  (Course may be repeated for a maximum of 3 credit hours.)  (This course is only offered as P/NC.)
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 10300, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites:   Dance Major or permission of instructor. May be repeated for credit.  This course will explore a specific somatic modality that may include but is not limited to: Gyrotonic®, Gyrokinesis®, Feldenkreis, Hamilton Floor Barre, Floor Barre, Alexander Technique®, or other somatic practice based in the faculty member's expertise. 1 credit. May be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major and Honors standing.  A supervised research experience in dance studies.  The topic will be determined in consultation with the supervising professor.  Topics may be focused on, but are not limited to, aspects of performance, choreography, history, education or aesthetics.  Performance may be an aspect of the course.  Arrangements for the course, which is offered only as a tutorial, must be made with an instructor prior to enrollment.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and Honors standing

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Dance major.  This seminar course is an exploration of dance-related topics providing frameworks for professional success in the field.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: DANC 30100 or 30200 or permission of the instructor.  This course explores the theory and practice of teaching Creative Movement for young children.  Students will learn to design and implement classes that harness the elements of dance - body, time, space and energy - to the end of stimulating creative investigation via movement.  1-3 credit hours.
courses.prerequisites: DANC 30100 or 30200 or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: DANC 20322, Dance Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet and/or Modern Dance technique class, or permission of the instructor.  As dance majors further their choreographic skills, focus centers on developing content, defining structure and learning to manipulate choreographic devises.  Creativity and critical analysis are essential components of coursework.
courses.prerequisites: DANC 20322, Dance Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet and/or Modern Dance technique class, or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 20333, or permission of instructor.  This course will provide students with the information and practical experience to create and implement lighting design for dance.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 20333, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: DANC 20100 and 20200 or permission of instructor.  Physical Theatre is a contemporary, hybrid art form developed within European culture.  Program participants will move between hands-on practice - developing and testing ideas in the studio - and historical, aesthetic and critical investigation of the form.  Study in the UK will be augmented by attendance at an international festival to view and respond to physical theatre in live performance.
courses.prerequisites: DANC 20100 and 20200 or permission of instructor

The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor.  Independent project supervised by faculty. (0.5 - 3 credit hours per course.)  May be repeated for credit.

courses.description:

Daily training in the contemporary practice of classical ballet at the advanced/professional level.  (2.0 - 2.5 hours maximum per semester. Course

courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 30221. This course is an advanced Pilates course and third in the Practica I-IV series. Content in Practica I-IV is progressive and moves the student toward the completion of comprehensive professional training in the Pilates system addressing skills, theory, history, teaching practice and philosophy.

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 40211. This course is an advanced Pilates course and fourth in the Practica I-IV series. Content in Practica I-IV is progressive and moves the student toward the completion of comprehensive professionaltraining in the Pilates system addressing skills, theory, history, teaching practice and philosophy.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 40211

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor.  Dancers are challenged to enhance performance abilities and further develop artistry.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 40373 and 40383, or permission of instructor, and completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803.  This course uses critical theories and research methodologies as frameworks through which to analyze various phenomena in Dance
Studies.  UCR:  TCU CC: Humanities, Writing Emphasis
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 40373 and 40383, or permission of instructor, and completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major and concurrent enrollment in daily dance technique course; DANC 20100, 20200, 30100, 30200, 40100, 40200, or 40150.  This course is a continuation of DanceTCU I for Junior and Senior dance majors.  Students earn the opportunity - via audition or casting process - to perform in either a faculty or guest artist work.  Through the performance experience, advanced dancers utilize dance technique and mature artistry developed in ballet and modern dance courses.  This course may be repeated for credit up to 2 hours, .5 credit hour per semester.  (1.5 hours minimum required for dance majors.)
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and concurrent enrollment in daily dance technique course; DANC 20100, 20200, 30100, 30200, 40100, 40200, or 40150

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major and Honors standing.  A supervised research experience with a thesis that is usually based on work completed in DANC 30303. Arrangements for the course, which is offered only as a tutorial, must be made with an instructor prior to enrollment.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and Honors standing

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 20333, or permission of instructor. This
course offers students the opportunity to explore the principles and techniques for
creating video dance works. Course may be repeated for credit.
courses.prerequisites: Dance Major and DANC 20333, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: DANC 30332, Dance Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet and/or Modern Dance technique class, or permission of the instructor.  Advanced exploration of the form and content of contemporary choreography culminating in production of original dance works including the integration of theatrical production elements. Critical response skills will be fine-tuned.
courses.prerequisites: DANC 30332, Dance Major and concurrent enrollment in Ballet and/or Modern Dance technique class, or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor and successful completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803. This course examines the development of dance from a global perspective.  Beginning in antiquity and culminating with the early Renaissance, it investigates social conditions, political situations, religious customs, cultural traditions, and economic contexts for the development of dance forms across the world.
courses.prerequisites: Dance major or permission of instructor and successful completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Prerequisites: DANC 40373, dance major or permission of instructor, and successful completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803. This course examines the context and lineage of Western Concert Dance from the Renaissance to the present day: it analyzes historical trends and their development over time; it attends to notable figures and seminal dance works; and it traces the migrations of Western Concert dance throughout Europe, Russia, and North America.
courses.prerequisites: DANC 40373, dance major or permission of instructor, and successful completion of ENGL 10803 and 20803

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description:
Prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 40343 or permission of instructor.  A capstone course giving the BFA candidate an opportunity to thoroughly explore, develop, edit and produce a project for performance that demonstrates choreographic and/or performance crafting informed by artistic judgments and personal values. This course requires the integration of theatrical
production elements. CFA
courses.prerequisites: Dance major and DANC 40343 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: DANC
courses.description: Directed individual topics beyond the scope of existing coursework.  Students must first discuss the nature of intended studies and obtain written permission of the instructor.  (More than 3 hours per class requires permission of instructor.  May be repeated.)

courses.subject: DCDA
courses.description: This course is designed as an introduction to coding for students in the Humanities and/or the Digital Culture and Data Analytics (DCDA) Program. Hence, students will be introduced to the basics of a computer programming language (such as Python or R) as it pertains to the intellectual, cultural, and creative work central to the Humanities. Students may not receive credit for both WRIT 20833 and DCDA 20833.

courses.subject: DCDA
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Department permission and enrollment in the Digital Culture and Data Analytics (DCDA) minor.  A directed-study course open to Honors students enrolled in the Digital Culture and Data Analytics (DCDA) minor who wish to do research on a topic in Digital Culture and/or Data Analytics in preparation for writing the honors thesis in DCDA 40003 (Senior Honors Seminar).  Students are required to produce an annotated bibliography a clearly articulated thesis, and a detailed outline.
courses.prerequisites: Department permission and enrollment in the Digital Culture and Data Analytics (DCDA) minor

courses.subject: DCDA
courses.description: A directed study in Digital Culture and/or Data Analytics (DCDA).  A variety of special or one-time topics in DCDA may be covered in this class.  The format may vary by semester.  1-3 semester hours.  This course may be repeated for credit.

courses.subject: DCDA
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: DCDA
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Department permission and DCDA 30003 with a grade of B or better.  A directed-study course open to Honors students enrolled in the Digital Culture and Data Analytics (DCDA) minor for writing the honors thesis based on research conducted in DCDA 30003 (Junior Honors Seminar).  The completed project must be approved by two faculty members affiliated with the DCDA program.
courses.prerequisites: Department permission and DCDA 30003 with a grade of B or better

courses.subject: DCDA
courses.description: Prerequisites: 60 credit hours; major GPA of 3.0 or Cum GPA of 2.8 minimum; approval of the department.  Students place themselves with companies, agencies, or non-profit organizations for workplace experience. Duties -- varied to fit the needs and opportunities associated with the participating entity -- generally include students utilizing their proficiencies in digital content creation and/or data analysis. Course may be repeated once for credit.
courses.prerequisites: 60 credit hours; major GPA of 3

courses.subject: DCDA
courses.description: Prerequisites: Either MATH 10043 or INSC 20153.  Also, one of the following: GEOG 30323, WRIT 20833, or COSC 10603.  This course is designed as a capstone experience for students in the Digital Culture & Data Analytics (DCDA) program.  Hence, the course is designed to give students the opportunity to develop a semester-long project that will allow them to practice, reflect upon, and publicly showcase their work as students in the DCDA program.
courses.prerequisites: Either MATH 10043 or INSC 20153

courses.description: Dermatology; home elective, clinical

courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: Prerequisites:  The course is required of all students in the Revised DMin Program that starts Fall 24.  The course equips DMin students with the skills necessary to engage in original research and to compose a doctoral level project or thesis.  The course will be offered in different terms by different Brite Divinity School faculty members.
courses.prerequisites: The course is required of all students in the Revised DMin Program that starts Fall 24

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: Prerequisites: Acceptance to the D.Min. program.  This common core D.Min. course examines developments in a particular area of theological study and their impact on Christian ministry.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance to the D

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admittance to the D.Min. Program.  May be repeated under different topics for up to twelve credit hours.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the D

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: This course assists students in developing a better understanding of their past-present-future Pastoral Identity within the broader context of their life and ministry.

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: This course assists students in enhancing their understanding of their social location as minister and how social and economic issues affect the experiences of believers within Christian communities.

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: This is the foundational seminar for Brite's Doctor of Ministry Program.  The course will introduce students to Brite's ethos and to the core concepts of the program: spirituality, leadership, and justice.  Students will explore models for integrating theology and practice, and for doing research and writing in ministry and theology.

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: This course is one of three courses required in the Doctor of Ministry program.  In this course, students will explore various methods and models for doing research and writing about theological reflection on ministry.  This course provides the opportunity to develop a plan for formulating and completing the ministry project.  Since the intent of the course is to assist with the development of a research proposal for the Doctor of Ministry project, the course is most helpful to participants after they have taken at least 1/3 of their course work.

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: Prerequisites:  The course is required of all students in the Revised DMin Program that starts Fall 24.  The course considers the practice of ministry in light of and in dialogue with advances in any particular academic theological discipline (e.g.Bible, Church History, Ethics, etc.).  The course will be offered in different terms by different Brite Divinity School faculty members.
courses.prerequisites: The course is required of all students in the Revised DMin Program that starts Fall 24

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admittance to the D.Min. program and completion of 24 hours of course work. Implementation, writing, and oral defense of D.Min. project.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the D

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admittance to the D.Min program and completion of 27 hours of course work.   The design, writing, and oral defense of the DMin project/thesis.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the D

courses.subject: DOMI
courses.description: Prerequisites:  The course is required of all students in the Revised DMin Program that starts Fall 24.  The course assists DMin students in developing a doctoral level project or thesis.  The course will be offered in different terms by different Brite Divinity School faculty members.
courses.prerequisites: The course is required of all students in the Revised DMin Program that starts Fall 24

courses.description:
An introduction to and overview of creative practices used in the
applied arts, design, and communication professions.

courses.subject: DSGN
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Permission of instructor. An introduction to drawing as practiced in applied design disciplines.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: DSGN
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Permission of Instructor. Study of two-dimensional design as it applies to design disciplines.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of Instructor

courses.subject: DSGN
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  Permission of Instructor. Study of light and color as it applies to design
disciplines.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of Instructor

courses.subject: DSGN
courses.description: Prerequisite:   Permission of Instructor. Study of three-dimensional form and composition as it applies to design disciplines.
courses.prerequisites: Permission of Instructor

courses.subject: DSGN
courses.description: An introduction to and overview of the use of computers in graphic design.  Emphasis on skills, including understanding and using the current graphic design software.  This includes page-layout, vector-based drawing, scanning and image enhancement/manipulation.

courses.subject: DSGN

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Overview of economics, introduction to microeconomic theory and policy; demand, supply, price determination in product and factor markets, principle of comparative advantage, concept of economic efficiency, perfect and imperfect competition.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Introduction to macroeconomic theory and policy; measurement of economic aggregates, inflation, unemployment, business cycles, fiscal and monetary policies, economic growth, exchange rates, balance of payments, and financial capital flows.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisite: Concurrent registration in, or completion of, ECON 10223.  Use of computer simulations, games, and formal exercises to build on and to reinforce, concepts and procedures covered in ECON 10223.
courses.prerequisites: Concurrent registration in, or completion of, ECON 10223

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisite: Concurrent registration in, or completion of, ECON 10233.  Use of computer simulations, games, and formal exercises to build on and to reinforce, concepts and procedures covered in ECON 10233.
courses.prerequisites: Concurrent registration in, or completion of, ECON 10233

courses.description: Topics may vary each time it is offered.

courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisite: Advanced standing in Economics and recommendation of the Chairman. Discussion of important books in the literature of economics and of significant economic problems.
courses.prerequisites: Advanced standing in Economics and recommendation of the Chairman

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 or 30223, or 31223, and 10233 or 30233.  An analysis of the changes that must take place in a society in order for economic development to proceed. Economic Theories of development and growth.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 or 30223, or 31223, and 10233 or 30233

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description:
Prerequisites: A C- or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, and either MATH 10283 or MATH 10524.  Microeconomics studies the behavior of individual economic agents and their interactions. Topics covered include consumer behavior and demand theory, the theory of the firm, gains from trade, market structure, and market failures. Credit not awarded for both ECON 30223
and ECON 31223.
courses.prerequisites: A C- or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, and either MATH 10283 or MATH 10524

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course. Employment, monetary theory, aggregate demand and supply theory, economic performance and tools of measurement.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisite: At least three semester hours credit in economics with a grade of 'C-' or better.  A survey of major theoretical approaches in economics today, with emphasis on the unique insights and applications of each approach, the theoretical underpinnings of enduring disagreements among professional economists, and the process of ongoing debate and cross-fertilization among these contending perspectives.
courses.prerequisites: At least three semester hours credit in economics with a grade of 'C-' or better

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in three semester hours of Economics. The study of economic ideas. May include the ideas of any major contributor from Adam Smith to contemporary economists.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in three semester hours of Economics

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 or 30223 or 31223, and 10233 or 30233.  Survey of development experience in a country or group of countries or analysis of general development experiences such as external finance, foreign trade and payments, development policy sets, or other experiences typical of developing countries.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 or 30223 or 31223, and 10233 or 30233

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any six hours of Economics.  Examines the modern development and economic history of East Asia from the 19th century to the present.  Topics include explanations for the rapid economic growth in the region; the impact of industrial policies, trade, and foreign direct investment; the origins of the Asian financial crisis; the role of demographic and institutional factors.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any six hours of Economics

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course.  This course is concerned with the process of economics integration within the European Union.  The main fields covered are: 1) Historical background, principles and functioning of the EU institutions; 2) the internal market: integration of product and factor markets; 3) EU policies (agriculture, regional, competition, etc.); 4) EU monetary integration.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course.  ECON 10233 is recommended, but not required.  This course covers the influence of past economic policies on the current state of the economics of Latin America.  The major policies to be considered are industrial policy, international trade policy, exchange rate policy, financing current account deficits, and macroeconomic policy.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 or 30223 or 31223.  An introduction to, and overview of, regional and urban economic theory.  Examination of location factors and costs including transportation rate structures, migration, firm location, structure of regions and urban areas, and urban problems.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 or 30223 or 31223

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in 6 hours of Economics. Examines important topics in the development of American and Western European monetary and financial systems. Historical perspectives on innovation, stabilization, and regulation within the major themes of monetary regimes, banking systems, and capital markets.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in 6 hours of Economics

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: At least three 3 semester hours credit in economics with a grade of 'C-' or better. Detailed analysis of current problems in international economic relationships. The list of topics selected on the basis of their significance in policy design, policy analysis, or contemporary economic well-being.
courses.prerequisites: At least three 3 semester hours credit in economics with a grade of 'C-' or better

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A C- or better in any 3 or more semester-hour ECON course.  Health Economics examines the determinants of health and health related behaviors, disease prevention and health promotion, health disparities and the impacts of health policy in bettering health outcomes.  The course also examines the market for health insurance and health care services, focusing on the behaviors of consumers, providers of medical care, and the impact of policy on the price and quantity of health care services.
courses.prerequisites: A C- or better in any 3 or more semester-hour ECON course

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: ECON 30223 or 31223 for economics majors; ECON 10223 for all others.  This course examines issues regarding the use and management of natural resources from the perspective of economics.  Topics include the valuation of natural resources, efficient extraction models for non-renewable resources, efficient allocation of water and land, and sustainable development of fishery.  This course will also explore issues in energy economics, including the market structure of oil and natural gas, the environmental impacts of energy use, and the transition to renewable energy sources.
courses.prerequisites: ECON 30223 or 31223 for economics majors; ECON 10223 for all others

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:  ECON 30223 or 31223 for economics majors; ECON 10223 for all others.  This course examines modern environmental issues from an economic perspective.  Topics include economic causes of environmental degradation, efficiency in environmental protection, benefit-cost analysis, non-market valuation, environmental policy and special topic on global climate change.  Emphasis is on the role of economics in the formation of environmental policy.
courses.prerequisites: ECON 30223 or 31223 for economics majors; ECON 10223 for all others

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, or instructor permission.  This course examines the transformation of Western Europe from a pre-modern and medieval world, to a society on the verge of industrialization.  Students investigate the technological, social and especially economic, changes that took place during this period and their effects.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, or instructor permission

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:  A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, or instructor permission.  This course examines the transformation of Western Europe from a pre-industrial society to the world's first highly industrialized economy from an economic perspective.  The later relative (not absolute) decline of Western Europe is also examined.  The focus is on the years from roughly 1700 to 1950.  Students investigate the technological, social, and especially economic changes that took place during this period, as well as their importance.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, or instructor permission

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisite: A C- or better in ECON 10223 or ECON 10233.  Economic Geography is the study of how elements within the economy are spatially arranged, as well as the ways that space, place and spatial scales shape economic activities in different parts of the world.  Through a series of readings, discussions, and research assignments, this course examines the distribution economic activities on the earth's surface; market resource and transportation factors in location theory, and the role of state, market and civil society's agents in management of the economy.  Students are further introduced to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) through content-focused lab assignments, though no previous experience with GIS is required for this course.
courses.prerequisites: A C- or better in ECON 10223 or ECON 10233

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:  3 hours of any economics course.  Public choice theory is the application of economic theory to non-market decision-making, specifically in the political sphere.  It assumes the same principles that economists use to analyze actions in the marketplace - people are primarily driven by self-interest - and applies them to analyze choices made collectively (such as the outcomes of elections or how to govern common pool resources).
courses.prerequisites: 3 hours of any economics course

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisite: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, and either MATH 10283 or MATH 10524. Microeconomics studies the behavior of individual economic agents and their interactions.  Topics covered include consumer behavior and demand theory, the theory of the firm, gains from trade, market structure, and market failures. This course takes a more mathematical approach to the topics covered in ECON 30223. Credit not awarded for both ECON 30223 and ECON 31223.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in any 3 or more semester hours ECON course, and either MATH 10283 or MATH 10524

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30003 with recommendation of the Department. Each student will prepare a substantial paper under the direction of a faculty member.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30003 with recommendation of the Department

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: ECON 30223 or 31223, 30233, 30243 and 12 additional ECON hours, all with grades of 'C-' or better. Capstone seminar exploring selected issues in economic theory or policy.
courses.prerequisites: ECON 30223 or 31223, 30233, 30243 and 12 additional ECON hours, all with grades of 'C-' or better

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223.  Theoretical and empirical examination of the interrelationships between market structure, conduct and performance in the industrial sector of the economy.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description:
Prerequisites: ECON 10223 or ECON 10233, INSC 20153 or MATH 10043.  
Game theory, also known as multi-person decision theory, analyzes situations in which payoffs to players depend on the behavior of other players as well as the player herself.  The purpose of this course is to introduce the basics of game theory to undergraduate students in various disciplines.  It focuses on fundamentals of game theory including basic concepts and techniques, various ways of describing and solving games, and various applications in economics, political sciences, and business.  It will help students sharpen their understanding of strategic behavior in different situations involving many individuals.  The students will learn how to recognize and model strategic situations, to predict when and how their action will have an influence on others, and to exploit strategic situations for the benefit of their own.
courses.prerequisites: ECON 10223 or ECON 10233, INSC 20153 or MATH 10043

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223. Economic analysis of labor market issues, including minimum wage legislation, compensating wage differentials, human capital investment, discrimination, and collective bargaining.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223 or 30233.  Theory of public choice; budgeting procedures; theory and methods of financing government expenditures; fiscal policy.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223 or 30233

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233 or FINA 30203. Analysis of the structure and operations of financial markets and analysis of the role of money and capital markets in the economy.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233 or FINA 30203

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223.  Surveys of international trade relationships, balance of payments accounting, theories explaining the pattern of trade and its relationship to economic welfare, policies affecting the pattern of a country's trade with the rest of the world.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30223 or 31223

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233. Surveys of various theories of exchange rate determination, along with evaluation of fixed, flexible and mixed exchange rate regimes. In addition, long-term and short-term capital flows are described and explained.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 OR 30223 OR 31223, and 10233 OR 30233, and MATH 10043 or MATH 30853 or INSC 20153. Techniques of simple and multiple regression. Methods for correcting problems of autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity, and multicollinearity.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 10223 OR 30223 OR 31223, and 10233 OR 30233, and MATH 10043 or MATH 30853 or INSC 20153

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:  A 'C-' or better in: ECON 10223 (Intro Microeconomics) or 30223 (Intermediate Microeconomics) or 31223 (Intermediate Microeconomics: Mathematical Approach), and ECON 10233 (Intro Macroeconomics) OR 30233 (Intermediate Macroeconomics), and MATH 10043 (Elementary Statistics) or MATH 30853 (Statistics) or INSC 20153 (Statistical Analysis)
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in: ECON 10223 (Intro Microeconomics) or 30223 (Intermediate Microeconomics) or 31223 (Intermediate Microeconomics: Mathematical Approach), and ECON 10233 (Intro Macroeconomics) OR 30233 (Intermediate Macroeconomics), and MATH 10043 (Elementary Statistics) or MATH 30853 (Statistics) or INSC 20153 (Statistical Analysis)

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in 6 hours of Economics.  Historical development of the United States economy from European contact through the antebellum period.  Emphasis is on colonial and pre-industrial development
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in 6 hours of Economics

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in 6 hours of Economics.  Historical development of the United States economy from the early national period to the modern era.  Emphasis is on the transition from a pre-industrial economy to an industrial economy with modern financial and governmental institutions.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in 6 hours of Economics

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: ECON 30243.  Law and Economics asks students to consider economics as a justification for legal decision making.  Different perspectives regarding the nature of law are juxtaposed against different perspectives regarding the nature of economics.  Students develop their own synthesis by examining landmark legal cases from various perspectives.
courses.prerequisites: ECON 30243

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:   A 'C-' or better in ECON 30243.  This course examines the nature and causes of differences in economic welfare correlated with race, ethnicity, and gender. Basic background concepts such as implicit bias and the social construction of race, ethnicity, and gender are introduced along with rival economic theories purporting to explain the observed patterns. These theories will vary from those attributing differences to personal characteristics and choices to those arguing that systemic factors, privilege, and oppression play the decisive role.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30243

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233 or graduate standing in business.  Analysis of macroeconomic issues in theory and policy from the perspective of competing schools of thought.  Special emphasis will be placed on how each approach explains post-1970 business cycles, inflation, and unemployment in the U.S. economy.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233 or graduate standing in business

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:  A 'C-' in ECON 30233 and a 'C-' in INSC 20153, MATH 10043, or 30853.  Introduces students to advanced theories of the business cycle, inflation, and other macroeconomic phenomena and shows them how to interpret real world data in the context of those theories with the goal of explaining and predicting trends. Students are further instructed on the art of communicating their findings to specific non-economist audiences in terms of the latter¿s genre conventions, content expectations, and language dynamics. The class culminates with the creation of a report on contemporary macroeconomic conditions that will be shared publicly online.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' in ECON 30233 and a 'C-' in INSC 20153, MATH 10043, or 30853

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30243.  Analysis of international trade theory, economics development, and exchange rates and capital flows from the perspective of competing schools of thought.  Special emphasis is placed on how the unique foundational elements of each lead to significantly different interpretations of the vary same real-world phenomena.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30243

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: Vary according to nature of material. For use when instructor has new material or new teaching strategies which are not appropriate to existing courses.
courses.prerequisites: Vary according to nature of material

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:  18 hours in economics, an overall GPA of 3.25, a GPA in Economics of 3.5, and senior standing.  The course will consist of supervised reading, research, and preparation of a substantial paper.  The course content cannot duplicate an already existing TCU economics course.  Students must receive preliminary approval from the department chair before developing a course plan with a faculty member.
courses.prerequisites: 18 hours in economics, an overall GPA of 3

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Must be an Economics major with a TCU cumulative GPA of at least 3.0.  Must have completed a minimum of 12 hours in Economics, including either ECON 30223 or ECON 30233 with a grade of C- or better.  The purpose of this course is to supplement the internship experience of economics majors through written reflection, periodic conversation with a supervising professor, and exploration of connections between academic economics and economics as understood and practiced in the workplace.  Must work 90 hours for each semester hour of credit.  May be taken a maximum of two times to earn up 6 total credit hours.  A maximum of 3 credit hours can be applied towards the Economics major.  P/NC only.
courses.prerequisites: Must be an Economics major with a TCU cumulative GPA of at least 3

courses.subject: ECON
courses.description: Prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233 or graduate standing in business.  Analysis of current macroeconomic issues in theory and policy.  Topics may include economic growth, fluctuations in business activity, investment behavior, consumption functions, macroeconomic planning, and the policy formulation process.
courses.prerequisites: A 'C-' or better in ECON 30233 or graduate standing in business

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  Relationships between different organizational patterns and administrative practices will be explored as well as the role of authority and decision making structures. Required of all majors in Educational Administration.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admitted to Graduate Education.  It will include concepts and issues derived from leadership, supervision, and law.
courses.prerequisites: Admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admitted to Graduate Education.  Foci will include community relations, communication, creating orderly, productive learning environments, and law.
courses.prerequisites: Admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  The course will normally be taught collaboratively with practicing administrators.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  This course is normally taken concurrently with EDAD 70200 Internship in Educational Administration. The course synthesizes prior course work, integrates new experiences from the Internship, and considers the alternatives each individual confronts in developing an administrative life, the jobs, technical and ethical demands, stresses and satisfactions.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: This course may be taken twice for a total of 2 semester hours.

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admitted to Graduate Education.  This course will examine the professional and intellectual history of educational administration.
courses.prerequisites: Admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  Educational institutions operate within an environment that requires relationships with families, employees, and other private and public institutions.  The primary focus of this course will be state and federal laws that regulate these relationships, with attention paid as well to social and political forces that influence the enforcement of laws.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  High achieving districts are led by administrators that focus on academic programs, set attainable goals, continuously assess the curriculum, evaluate staff and teachers, and assess student achievement.  This course will highlight the importance of instructional leadership and of developing effective evaluation processes as well as professional development opportunities.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to a graduate program within the College of Education or admission to a graduate program outside of the College of Education and permission of the instructor. This course emphasizes enduring educational problems and fundamental philosophical issues, concepts that feature centrally in educational discourse, ethical standards and dilemmas, and conceptual analysis as a means for clarifying decisions regarding educational policy and practice. The course also attends to the intersection of ethical decision-making in educational contexts and various conceptions and applications of equity (e.g., equity initiatives, but also equity as it is centered or decentered within decision-making around a range of school district functions, from resource allocation to testing/student placement, to a range of student and school outcomes, to human resource functions).
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a graduate program within the College of Education or admission to a graduate program outside of the College of Education and permission of the instructor

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to a graduate program within the College of Education or admission to a graduate program outside of the College of Education and permission of the instructor.  This course investigates the formation, implementation, and evaluation of educational policy in educational systems, and the role that policy plays at the federal, state, and locals levels specific to school finance. The leader's/administrator's role in creating/sponsoring, utilizing and adapting policy will be of core concern. The course will also focus on the political processes associated with school finance in terms of school funding, resource allocation, and the role of school finance equity in promoting or hindering school efforts at leveraging improved outcomes.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to a graduate program within the College of Education or admission to a graduate program outside of the College of Education and permission of the instructor

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Admission to the Ed.D. Program or permission of the instructor.  Empirical research on topics in education is frequently conducted using methods particular to the discipline of economics.  Given the complex nature of the education process, it is not surprising that studies examining the same issue often reach different, often contradictory, conclusions.  This course will systematically examine literature related to the economics of education.

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admission to the Graduate School at TCU and the College of Education Ed.D. program, or permission of the instructor.  This course will explore various aspects of educational data use from a leadership perspective.  Practitioner texts and peer-reviewed scholarship will be used to inform dialogue and class activities and assignments.  The course will equip students with practical tools to address aspects of sustainable and effective date use in the now, and will engage students in academic dialogues that help them address data-related issues still on the educational horizon.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Graduate School at TCU and the College of Education Ed

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  PhD students must have completed at least 45 hours of doctoral coursework, and should have completed comprehensive exams successfully by the time they take the course. EdD students registered for this course must have completed at least 18 hours of doctoral coursework. This course (for PhD students) or sequence of courses (for EdD students) is aimed at ensuring that students are fully prepared to begin work on the capstone project or dissertation and are able to demonstrate a range of skills and abilities, including an ability to frame a capstone project or dissertation; undertake an appropriate literature review; make decisions regarding design and implementation of the project or study, and, in other respects, complete the qualifying process.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  Planned program of leadership responsibilities in an educational institution or agency, commensurate with the student's graduate program, certification objectives, and employment goals. Emphasis on research application in a field-based setting. Responsibilities and projects are under the direction of the academic advisor and on-site supervisor.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisite: Must be admitted to Graduate Education.  A semester-long internship providing leadership experiences in an educational or corporate setting commensurate with the student's doctoral program.  This course can be repeated three times for a total of 18 semester hours.
courses.prerequisites: Must be admitted to Graduate Education

courses.subject: EDAD
courses.description: Prerequisites: Completion of all Ed.D. coursework, including EDAD 70073, Capstone Doctoral Seminar and approval of doctoral advisory committee.  Students will propose and execute an approved capstone project, submit the written documentation and publicly present the capstone project as directed by their doctoral advisory committee.  The capstone project replaces the traditional dissertation.  A minimum of 9 credit hours are required; more hours may be taken when necessary.
courses.prerequisites: Completion of all Ed

courses.subject: EDCS
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admission into graduate studies or permission of instructor.  Each semester, the colloquium addresses a different contemporary problem significant to curriculum studies.  Through readings, discussions, and presentations of scholarly activities; student will explore the semester's theme, further their knowledge of curriculum studies, and develop academic talents within a community of scholars.  Non-Curriculum Studies students may join the colloquium with permission of instructor.
courses.prerequisites: Admission into graduate studies or permission of instructor

courses.subject: EDCS
courses.description: The Colloquium in the Profession of Curriculum Studies is designed as an introduction to the practical and theoretical issues of the field for all first semester graduate students.  Class sessions may include presentations made by faculty or students; lectures by guest speakers; round table on specific educational issues; attendance at professional conferences; or informational meetings.

courses.subject: EDCS
courses.description: Prerequisites: EDCS 70963.  In Teaching Diversity, doctoral students join Curriculum Studies faculty for co-teaching and teaching under faculty supervision the course EDUC 50003: Diversity in American Education.  Course work includes course design, lectures, facilitation, student interaction, and assessment.  Time requirements will include preparation before class, scheduled class periods and events, and follow-up responsibilities after class.
courses.prerequisites: EDCS 70963

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: This course is designed to build the content knowledge and skills needed by Pre-Kindergarten through sixth grade teachers.  The science content emphasized in this course aligns with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) as well as the content mandated by the State of Texas.  The course will model inquiry teaching, engage students in constructivist science inquiry, and provide students with the materials needed to successfully teach science.  It will build student understanding of science concepts through active learning experiences. This course is required for acceptance into the EC-6 program in the college of Education.

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Issues in professional and legal responsibilities and certification standards.  This course is available only for Pass/No credit grades.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Issues in professional and legal responsibilities and certification standards.  This course is available only for Pass/No credit grades.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Concurrent enrollment in Junior 1 courses.  This course builds on EDEC 20013, Science for Elementary Teachers.  It will use the Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) as a framework to help students examine content methodology, skills, and materials used to teach science to children in elementary classrooms.  Students will engage in hands-on investigations, class discussions, readings and field placements with emphasis on developmentally appropriate practices in science instruction.  Procedures for planning, implementing, and reflecting on science instruction are learned in a school setting.  Topics from life, earth/space and physical science will be covered.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  This is a required course in the ECE Junior 1 Block.  Using the guidelines set forth by the National Council of Texas of Mathematics and the State of Texas for mathematics instruction, the students will develop pedagogical content knowledge related to the development of conceptual understanding of geometry and measurement.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program. This is a required course in the ECE Junior 1 Block.  With its theoretical and research-based framework, this course is designed to prepare students to support development, health, and learning through play.  Students learn developmentally appropriate strategies for promoting creative thinking, inquiry, and self-expression in core content areas and the fine arts.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: This course offers an introduction to the analytical study of children's literature with a focus on children's books that focus on complex societal topics.  We will explore books that address topics such as poverty, immigration, race, sexuality, war, and the Holocaust.  We will study novels, picture books, and film. This course will enhance student understanding of people and cultures throughout the world.

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Directed toward affecting prospective early childhood teachers' insights with regard to current issues and trends in early childhood education; curricula and assessment appropriate for a range of early childhood settings; and developmentally appropriate practice for young children ages birth to age 8.  Classroom practicum is required.

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Concurrent enrollment in EDEC 30123.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  This is a required course in the ECE Junior 2 Block.  Using the guidelines set forth by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics and the State of Texas for mathematics instruction, the students will develop pedagogical content knowledge related to the development of conceptual understanding of data analysis and probability.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  This is a required course in the ECE Junior 1 Block.  This course examines principles of literacy learning in young children through grade six.  The course introduces theories, practices and materials for teaching writing in the elementary through middle level grades (EC-6)
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Concurrent enrollment in Junior block courses.  Focuses on the study of the nature of literacy and second language learning processes, including the Science of Teaching Reading, and the relationship among these processes, young children, teachers, curriculum, and instruction.  Emphasis is given to the guidance of students as they progress through the continuum of literacy abilities in phonics, decoding, vocabulary and comprehension in grades PK-2.  Introduces recent research, philosophies of instruction, curriculum development, literature, and assessments that can be used to improve students' reading and language abilities.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Concurrent enrollment in Junior II courses.  Principles and practices of first and second language acquisition in early childhood settings.  Emphasis on the interrelatedness of language processing (reading, writing, speaking and listening) to facilitate the learner's ability to construct meaning.  Strategies to enhance social-communicative and cognitive-academic language competencies are addressed.  Assessment procedures appropriate to English language learners (ELL) are introduced.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Concurrent enrollment in Junior block courses.  Curricular and instructional principles and practices to meet the academic development needs of first and second language learners in the classroom.  Emphasis on strategies for providing content-area instruction and establishing learner-centered environments within various elementary school ESL settings.  Texas requirements for second language learners are addressed.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description:
Prerequisite: Admission to Teacher Education.  Based on state and national standards, theory, and research and with particular emphasis on active citizenship
and diversity, this course introduces methods and resources for teaching social studies in EC-6 classrooms. Specific, practical methods for teaching social studies and integrating social studies disciplines with other content areas will be explored.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to Teacher Education

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program and concurrent enrollment in Senior I courses.  This course examines assessment and evaluation methods, strategies, and procedures within the classroom context.  Both formal and informal methods of gathering educational information and monitoring children's progress will be integral parts of this course.  Students learn how to develop appropriate assessments and interpret assessment information for educational program planning.  Students also learn how to make modifications and accommodations for testing students who are English language learners and students with disabilities.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program and concurrent enrollment in Senior I courses

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program, an Accelerated Masters program, and concurrent enrollment in Senior I courses.  Provides a foundation for key theory, policy, and research trends informing family-school partnership practices and programming across the general and special education contexts. Also students will learn communication skills and associated practices for building relationships with family members within their broader scope of practice. Students will be exposed to varieties of family forms through didactic, interpersonal, and community/practical experiences
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program, an Accelerated Masters program, and concurrent enrollment in Senior I courses

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Successful completion of EDEC 30223:  Education in Elementary Curriculum:  Reading in Grades PK-2.  Concurrent enrollment in Senior 1 courses.  In this 2-credit hour course, emphasis is given to the guidance of students as they progress through the continuum of literacy abilities in phonics, decoding, vocabulary and comprehension in grades 3-6.  Introduces recent research , philosophies of instruction, curriculum development, literature, and assessments that can be used to improve students' reading and abilities.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Successful completion of EDEC 30223:  Education in Elementary Curriculum:  Reading in Grades PK-2.  Concurrent enrollment in Senior 1 courses.  In this 3-credit hour course, emphasis is given to the guidance of students as they progress through the continuum of literacy abilities in phonics, decoding, vocabulary and comprehension in grades 3-6.  Introduces recent research, including the Science of Teaching Reading, philosophies of instruction, curriculum development, literature, and assessments that can be used to improve students' reading and abilities.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program and concurrent enrollment in Senior I courses.  This course covers content related to: designing effective classroom environments to support appropriate student behavior and prevent challenging behavior and designing individualized plans for students who require more intensive behavioral support.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program and concurrent enrollment in Senior I courses

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  Concurrent enrollment in Senior 1 courses.  This course provides field-based experience for students enrolled in the Senior 1 block.

courses.subject: EDEC
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admission to the Teacher Education Program.  This internship provides field-based experience for Senior I fall block coursework.
courses.prerequisites: Admission to the Teacher Education Program

courses.subject: EDEC
