In this discussion-centered course, we explore a series of unsettled questions in biology, psychology, medicine, and philosophy:  What is disease?  Are diseases purely biological conditions or is the very definition of disease shaped by society?  What does it mean to be healthy or normal?  Are psychiatric disorders real?  Are disabilities medical conditions or social ones?  No previous background in philosophy, science, or medicine is required.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  In this discussion-centered course, students explore and experience empathy in its individual, interpersonal, and civic modalities by way of readings in literature, psychology, sociology, philosophy, and a semester-long service-learning project with a local community partner.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  In this discussion-centered course, students employ tools of rhetoric, anthropology, sociology, and history to gain new perspectives on the games we watch and play, exploring the intimate links between sports, politics, religion, business, education, race, and gender.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course explores the use of design thinking principles to create innovative solutions to cultural and business problems.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course explores experiential and social dimensions of the Internet and social media.  Topics include aesthetics, entrepreneurship and labor, political change, gender and ethnicity, and privacy concerns.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course explores the causes of crime and the behavior of criminal organizations from the Civil War to the present, using concepts and readings from journalism, sociology, and literature to explore the social contexts and legends of infamous figures.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course examines pervasive and persistent patterns of racial imagery in mainstream U.S. cinema.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course examines the nature and significance of secular society through the lenses of multiple academic disciplines.  Topics include the historical forces that gave rise to secular society and the diverse forms of secularization throughout the world.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course empowers students to engage with activist art as critics, consumers, and creators, to challenge themselves and each other by interacting vigorously with a wide range of art works created with the goal of influencing thought and action.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This colloquium explores the social contexts and impacts of current controversies in policing ranging from police misconduct and racial profiling to community policing and media relations.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This colloquium examines topics in the philosophy of mind and cognitive science, including the mind-body problem, the hard problem of consciousness, the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis, artificial intelligence, and conceptual disputes in contemporary cognitive science.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This colloquium provides a humanistic exploration of what economists call specialization: the discovery and cultivation of one's unique talents, passions, and duties, not only in the realm of paid employment but in all parts of life.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This uniquely experiential course examines a range of social issues through the lenses of different cultural perspectives, using a virtual classroom to place TCU students in daily dialogue with students from one or two non-U.S. universities.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course examines, using the board game Go as a focal point and an exemplar, various aspects of East Asian cultures.  The relation between Asian culture and Western culture and the boundary between culture and natural science are also explored.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course examines the social, economic and political power that Black music has held in "fine tuning" a culture that has not always accepted the individuals who created it.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course explores the philanthropic sector and challenges students to work as a philanthropic foundation that gives funds to local non-profit organizations and as such must investigate, assess, and debate the relative merits of alternative funding targets.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course examines the ramifications of the theory of evolution for our understanding of culture and the world including the role of genetics, the example of great apes, religious interpretations of human origins, ecological interdependence, and gender.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course offers an interdisciplinary exploration of several Western and Eastern conceptions of mind, consciousness, and self through philosophical discussion as well as experiential exercise and exploration.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students use historical research methods and concepts from media studies to examine the meaning of journalistic truth, the role of moral courage in pursuit of journalistic truth, and role of journalism as a bulwark of freedom and human rights.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  This course examines the cycle of influence between media and society through critical examination of film, television, online video, video games and other forms of digital media.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Using research from psychology, evolutionary biology, nutrition, and neuroscience, students explore what research says about how we can be healthier, happier, and better connected to others.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students use the frameworks of design thinking and systems thinking to develop innovative, impactful solutions to complex social problems.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Through exploration of religious, political, historical, and fictional texts, students examine and evaluate contending responses to the enduring question of what it means to be a good citizen.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Through readings, film, discussion, writing, and a semester-long service-learning project, students explores critical questions about gender and sexuality in society.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students analyze the pervasive role of Islam in the cultural and political life of the Muslim World via exploration of topics such as Islam and terrorism, Islam and human rights, Islam and the Arab Spring, and the prospects for relations between the Muslim World and the West in an age of globalization and interdependence.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students examine issues of democracy, dissent, and debate in 21st century workplaces, exploring the nature, value, and scope of these ideals in a postmodern, corporatized society.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students examine the history and culture of Texas, drawing on popular song, literature and film as well as social science to hear the voices of many prominent Texans, particularly those of diverse and under-represented communities.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students examine the impact of the Walt Disney Company (including but not limited to its movies, merchandise, theme parks, and television programming) on a range of cultural, economic, and societal issues.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students explore the enduring fascination with Mary Shelley¿s Frankenstein, analyzing the contexts and ideas that influenced Shelley herself and the diverse legacies of Frankenstein in contemporary literature and film.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students trace political and social movements in the United States from the 1920s to the present through the lens of musical theater, exploring how issues of class, gender/sexuality, race, and national identity play out on the stage and screen.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students explore what it means to live a mindful life in the 21st century and the kinds of thinking and practices that such a life entails.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students examine the nature, value, and challenges of game-based learning in a variety of fields, exploring the work/play divide, gamification, and participatory culture.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students gain insight into a range of social and personal issues, from the climate change debate to medical advice from physicians, by examining key texts and ideas from the history of
science.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students draw upon the medical humanities, memoir, and science fiction to explore what caregiving and care ethics look like in a time when our own planet is facing a health crisis.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.   Students examine the future of American leadership in a rapidly changing global context.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Informed by the intersectional framework of Kimberlé Crenshaw, students in this course utilize the artistry, musicianship, and feminism of Beyoncé to explore societal issues of patriarchy, racism, classism, and sexism.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students critically and comparatively explore the depiction of monstrous parents (particularly mothers) in film, literature, and medical history.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Through comparative examination of English-language newspapers and news sites in over 100
countries, students identify cultural differences and similarities across nations and explore the tensions between globalization and cultural identity.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Through first-hand exposure to speeches and texts by former presidents and prime ministers across the Americas, students examine elements of executive leadership and advantages and
disadvantages of presidential and prime ministerial systems.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description:
Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College.  Using learning materials and perspectives from multiple disciplines and cultural contexts, students examine the internal and external resiliencies that allow humans to endure and thrive in
the most difficult of circumstances.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students study the narratives of pregnant people, using the methods of Narrative Medicine to understand how the power of story and how legal, political, medical, and cultural circumstances shape personal experiences of pregnancy and decisions around pregnancy care.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.   Students reflect upon cultural standards and norms embedded in contemporary novels and films, by means of which certain characters are rendered despicable, marginal, or lesser.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:   Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students in this site-based course learn to read the spaces around them as vibrant, evolving, historical texts.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.  Students examine the worldly nature and significance of games and gaming communities, in part by learning to play and reflect upon well-known video games.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College..  Students examine popular dystopic depictions of the future (via games, films, and literature), seeking to understand how technology changes our perceptions of reality and humanity.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:   Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors. Students examine hero myths across multiple cultural contexts to explore how they reflect and/or critique their cultural contexts while simultaneously shaping readers¿ cultural identities.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors.  Students use basic mathematics to understand the nature and significance of sustainability, climate change, and the tradeoffs facing us, individually and globally, in the 21st century.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors.  Students explore theories and forms of capitalism and socialism, past and present, seeking to understand their promises and failures to generate freedom, fairness, and prosperity for all.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors. Students seek to understand the present age by asking what is new about it compared to the era of modernity (1450-1918).
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors.  Students comparatively analyze how freedom is defined and achieved across various Western nations.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors.  Students study the goals and practices of Universities Studying Slavery, reflect on their own campus culture through this comparative lens, and consider additional ways to create a more inclusive and equitable campus community.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College and declared pursuit of University Honors

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College. This course explores the cultural phenomena of witches, witchcraft and witch hunts with a special focus on the 1692 Salem witch hysteria. The course includes examining primary and secondary sources, case studies, popular literature and movies to gain a greater understanding of the role that that witches and witchcraft play in contemporary society.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOL
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Acceptance into the Honors College.This course helps students develop a deeper understanding of the ideals, principles, and beliefs that guide their behavior and how they experience the world around them. Students will grapple with questions around sites of tragedy, monuments, and gentrification of communities. Through an interdisciplinary lens, students interrogate how place and space form our understanding of the world and ourselves.
courses.prerequisites: Acceptance into the Honors College

courses.subject: HCOM
courses.description: This class aims to provide you with an overview of the field of health communication and enhance your understanding about it.  Specifically, you will learn most studied major topical areas in healthcare and health communication, theories and methods used to guide health communication research and intervention, and design and evaluations of health campaigns.  Students may not receive credit for both HCOM 10313 and COMM 30313.

courses.subject: HCOM
courses.description: A beginning look at issues and opportunities in the areas of health, communication and media.  This class is designed to help students examine social and media forces of health communication that impact diverse groups.  Topics will include health promotion campaigns, media health edutainment, interpersonal health communication and media advocacy and outreach.

courses.subject: HCOM
courses.description: The quality of relational communication is fundamentally tied to human health.  This course aims to better understand how interpersonal communication affects people's physiological well-being by studying the health outcomes associated with relational processes like emotional expression, disclosure, affection, and conflict.

courses.subject: HCOM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  HCOM 10313 or 20303.  Globalization, technological advancement, and new media have been revolutionized and complicated issues in health communication and healthcare.  This class is designed to help students examine social and media forces of health communication that impact diverse groups in the 21st century.  We will take a close examination of the latest issues and opportunities in the areas of health, communication and media.  Topics will include e-health, m-health, telemedicine, health campaigns, culture and diversity in healthcare.

courses.subject: HCOM
courses.description: Prerequisites:  HCOM 10313 and 20303.  Learn how a health communication campaign is created and executed.  Students will utilize their accumulated knowledge from their minor courses to analyze health campaign case studies, then create and execute a health communication campaign as a team.
courses.prerequisites: HCOM 10313 and 20303

courses.subject: HCOM
courses.description: Prerequisite:  HCOM 10313 or 20303.  Specific topics requiring independent or small group research and study in health communication.

courses.subject: HEBI
courses.description: This course is a graduate level introduction to critical interpretation of the Hebrew Bible and Apocryphal/Deuterocanonical books focusing on content and context.  It will include a selective survey of the history, literature and religion of ancient Israel exploring in part the Torah (Pentateuch), Prophets (Former and Latter) and, Writings (Hebrew and Greek narrative, poetic and wisdom books).

courses.subject: HEBI
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: HEBI
courses.description: Prerequisite: HEBI 60003 or equivalent.  Methods and resources in critical study of selected passages or book in the Hebrew Bible, with attention to literary, historical, and theological considerations.  May be repeated for credit under different topics.

courses.subject: HEBI
courses.description: Prerequisite: HEBI 60003 or equivalent.  The Interpretation of the Major Prophets (First Isaiah, Jeremiah, and Exekiel).  The course focuses on the historical background, literary structure, sociocultural features, and religious themes of each of these prophets.

courses.subject: HEBI
courses.description: Prerequisite: HEBI 60003 or equivalent.  The interpretation of one or more of the Minor Prophets.  Methods and resources in the critical study of the Minor Prophets with attention to literary, historical, and theological considerations.
courses.prerequisites: HEBI 60003 or equivalent
