In this  course, we will critically examine the chemical and physical properties of water, the role water plays in shaping the world, and how water is essential for life.  As a class, we will analyze various ways to think about water, including as drinking water, a sanitation mechanism, and an economic resource.  The ultimate goal of this class is to help you develop a deeper understanding of water while developing your critical thinking, presentation skills and writing skills.
courses.prerequisites: A senior high school course in STEM field and Recipient of STEM Scholarship

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisite: Sophomore standing.  This study abroad course is for students who are driven with an entrepreneurial spirit and have a passion for technological innovation.  This course consists of lecture, invited speakers, case studies, and field trips.
courses.prerequisites: Sophomore standing

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: This is a one-hour exploratory course for students in the College of Science & Engineering, particularly those on the pre health track, who are seeking career information related to academic and occupational interest patterns outside of the pre health track with STEM degrees.  Students will be provided career development tools and resources such as career assessments, information on career options for their degree both traditional and non-traditional.  Students will also have the opportunity to participate in career planning as it pertains to their strengths, skills, and interests.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Two hours of lecture and two hours of laboratory.  Whiskey embodies multiple sciences and engineering.  Whiskey has played a significant role in history including that of the United States.  The course conveys elementary science concepts from the disciplines of chemistry, plant biology, genetics, neuroscience and engineering along with the historical underpinnings of these concepts as well as the impact that whiskey has had on US history since the colonial era up to and including multinational corporations.  Laboratory experiments are linked intimately to lecture content.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Whisky serves as a useful lens for looking at science, history, culture and their interdependence.  The course meets weekly for 2.5h in the spring semester to perform labs, discuss historical and cultural readings, and practice cultural activities.  During the term, the group travels to an environment (ie Scotland, Ireland, Japan) for approximately two weeks for immersion in the course material to allow synthesis.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description:
The advancements of science and technology have accelerated over the past century, leading to corresponding societal advances and impacts on different communities. While much of the public thinks these advances are natural, many are, in fact, the result of sustained commitment by the nation to support
science and technology through a deliberate set of policies. Federal policies affect science and technology on small and large scales, from undergraduate training grants to National Laboratories to State Department. Issues such as global climate change, energy sustainability, terrorism, nuclear proliferation, human genomics, and exponentially evolving technologies are among the most challenging and complex facing contemporary society and their impacts on local and native communities. This course will highlight the important role of national science policy in how science is used to affect large scale national and international policy decisions and how these decisions have or may impact minority and disadvantaged communities.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisites:  SCIE 10503 and Recipient of STEM Scholarship from TCU.  The course aims to introduce students to the different research opportunities, institutes, and initiatives in the College of Science and Engineering at TCU and beyond.  Research in the areas of Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Computer Sciences, Psychology and Engineering will be highlighted.  Students attend weekly meeting to discuss research opportunities in the College of Science and Engineering.  Students will also learn about summer research opportunities outside of TCU.
courses.prerequisites: SCIE 10503 and Recipient of STEM Scholarship from TCU

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: This course introduces new pre-health students to the concepts of readiness and expectations as a TCU pre-health student.  Students will learn about resources available from the Pre-health Professions Institute, activities and life experiences that will best prepare them for their undergraduate pre-health career, and how to foster a community of support with their peers.  Pass/No Credit grade basis only.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: This course will introduce students to critical global health concepts including the determinants of health, the measurements of health status, the importance of culture to health, the global burden of disease, key risk factors for different health conditions, demographic and epidemiological transitions, and the organization and functions of health systems.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description:
This course explores the relation between healthcare and visual culture of the human body. Drawing on a variety of academic disciplines and social productions, students will reflect on perceptions of the body and health in the historical and contemporary western, American medical context. Students will engage¿
and to a limited extent create¿visual media in conjunction with their course readings. This course is suited for those preparing for roles as healthcare professionals with the goal of developing empathetic ways of relating to others, namely patients suffering illness and in pain.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Topics of current interest.  May be repeated for credit when the topic changes.  (1-3 credit hours.)

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisites: ENGL 20803 or 20833.  This study abroad course examines the rise of both science and technology in western civilization and how they have shaped history, with particular focus on developments in England.  Includes visits to sites in London, Greenwich, Cambridge, and Oxford.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisite:  54 or more cumulative hours.  Two hours of lecture and two hours laboratory.  Whiskey embodies multiple sciences and engineering.  Whiskey has played a significant role in history including that of the United States.  The course conveys elementary science concepts from the disciplines of chemistry, plant biology, genetics, neuroscience and engineering along with the historical underpinnings of these concepts as well as the impact that whiskey has had on US history since the colonial era up to and including multinational corporations.  Laboratory experiments are linked intimately to lecture content.  Credit will not be granted for both SCIE 20303 and SCIE 30303.
courses.prerequisites: 54 or more cumulative hours

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description:
Prerequisites:   Senior Standing.  This capstone seminar course for the Cultural Awareness in Healthcare (CAH) minor will guide students through a process of synthesis and reflection based on each student¿s unique selection of coursework for the minor. Students will apply their knowledge and skills to the problem of
healthcare disparities (locally, regionally, and globally), demonstrate their ability to engage in collective dialogue, and learn to articulate their cultural competence for their future career in healthcare or related field. This course is intended for all students who have completed a minimum of 15 hours of the CAH minor coursework and are in the final semester(s) of their undergraduate degree plan.
courses.prerequisites: Senior Standing

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisite:  Sophomore standing.  This course explores the relation between religion and healthcare in the American medical context.  We will trace the historic interplay between religious practice and fostering human health in the West, with emphasis on the prominence of Christianity, the development of secularism, and religious plurality that marks contemporary healthcare.  This course is suited for those preparing for roles as healthcare professionals, with the goal of fostering cultural competence.
courses.prerequisites: Sophomore standing

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 30603 and CHEM 30123.  This course will introduce students to the concept of professionalism within a healthcare context and the core competencies that future healthcare providers should possess.  Students will reflect on how their work, activities and life experiences have prepared them for a career in healthcare.  Additionally, students will develop written and verbal communication skills applicable to health professions and the professional school application process.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 30603 and CHEM 30123

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisites:  Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve. Students serve as teaching assistants for professional development courses designed for Pre-Health students. Students receive one credit hour for every three hours of course-related duties per week including course staff meetings, consultations with students, assisting with grading and other duties as assigned.
courses.prerequisites: Written permission of the instructor of the course in which the student plans to serve

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisites:  BIOL 10503 and 10513.  Students will examine the dietary requirements of both animals and livestock and be exposed to basic anatomy, physiology and biochemistry of the gastrointestinal system, nutrient procurement and use, feed additives, growth stimulants, metabolic disease and diet therapy.
courses.prerequisites: BIOL 10503 and 10513

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisites  Students must be pursuing the cultural awareness and healthcare minor and have completed 60 hours of coursework.   This course is available to students pursuing the Cultural Awareness in Healthcare minor. Research and other scholarly experiences for advanced students.  Three clock hours per week of research are required for each semester hour of credit, for up to three semester hours credit in any given semester. This course can be repeated or taken in combination with SCIE 40633 for maximum of six hours of credit between the two courses.

courses.subject: SCIE
courses.description: Prerequisites:    Students must be in the honors college, be pursuing the cultural awareness and healthcare minor and have completed 60 hours of coursework.   This course is available to students in the Honors College pursuing departmental honors in Cultural Awareness in Healthcare. Research and other scholarly experiences for advanced students. Nine clock hours per week are required for a total of 135 hours. The results will be written in the form of a senior honors research thesis to be presented to the Honors College. A student may receive credit for this course only one time.
courses.prerequisites: Students must be in the honors college, be pursuing the cultural awareness and healthcare minor and have completed 60 hours of coursework

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Transfer work with TCUCC-SSC credit.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: General Transfer Credit-No Core

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Intro Soc-Transfer Credit, carrying TCUCC SSC credit.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: General Transfer Credit

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course explores differing patterns of human relationships; the course further applies sociological concepts so as to enrich the understanding of human behavior.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course presents information about a range of social problems (poverty, racism, sexual discrimination, crime, etc.) with emphasis on the relationship between the individual and the larger context within which the problems exist.  Additionally, fundamental societal institutions and theoretical issues will be explored.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Transfer work in Sociology.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: A directed study course open to honor students with 6 semester hours of sociology and/or permission of the students' adviser and the instructor. A sociological analysis of the interplay of ideological and social factors in the development and decline of social systems and of present trends in world ideologies and societies is emphasized, with some possible implications for the future.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOCI 20213.  This course introduces students to the field of applied sociology and prepares students for internships and career placement.  Students develop a better understanding of how sociological concepts, theory, methods, and findings are used in practice, especially in settings related to one's own career interest.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The study of selected topics of current interest and importance in sociology.  These topics will vary in accordance with the interests of student and faculty.  May be repeated for credit with different course content.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the concept of sustainability from a multidisciplinary perspective.  Sustainability includes a focus on the environment, social justice issues, and economic development that provides the basic needs for sustaining an acceptable quality of life.  A focus on the global implications will be stressed and students will explore the connections between sustainability and citizenship and social values.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20223, or permission of instructor.  A survey of the major forms of violence in contemporary society.  Examining the extent and distribution of violence and the sociological, anthropological and psychological theories devised to account for violence.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20223, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course examines the connection between the environment and society, from the local to the global level.  Environmental problems, and their potential solutions, can be extremely controversial points of discussion:  are humans doomed or will we overcome these problems?  In the course, we will look at debates related to energy resources, population growth, green consumerism, climate change, environmental justice, and other issues.  Students will engage in an experiential learning project where they attempt a personal change in their behavior in an effort to improve the environment.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisites:  SOCI 20213 or 20223 or ANTH 20623 or CRES 10103 or 20003.  Black, Indigenous, other people of color, working class, immigrant, women, and other marginalized groups bear the brunt of environmental problems in the United States and across the world, facing disproportionate impacts from things like air and water pollution, toxic chemicals, climate change, industrialization, and biodiversity loss. Why are certain groups systematically exposed to greater environmental burdens and fewer environmental amenities while other groups have access to clean air and water? What effect does this have on people's health and well-being? Who benefits from these inequalities and who makes decisions about environmental policies? This course draws on the work of sociologists and interdisciplinary scholars to examine how social, political, and economic systems create environmental injustices and health disparities across intersections of race, ethnicity, class, and gender. In turn, we explore how people work to remedy environmental problems. These lessons are applied to understanding, researching, and addressing contemporary environmental justice issues.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20223 or ANTH 20623 or CRES 10103 or 20003

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The course keys on macro and micro social factors that shape American families.  It explores the theoretical and empirical analyses of family dynamics and family policy.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of sociological and criminological theories of crime, criminality, and crime control.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course offers an overview of the field of cultural criminology, from its theoretical and historical foundations to its current developments.  The course explores the various intersections of culture, crime, and crime control, including criminal subcultures, crime and consumer culture, crime as pleasure and performance, and crime and crime control as public display.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description:
Prerequisite: SOCI 20213 or 20223, or permission of instructor.   This course explores race as a socially constructed category and examines theories of racism
at individual and institutional levels. The course addresses contemporary inequalities across different racial and ethnic groups.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20223, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: MATH 10043. An introduction to sociological research procedures, with emphasis on the collection, analysis and interpretation of both quantitative and qualitative data.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 10043

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of correctional agencies and programs, including the social structure of prisons and its impact on the offender, deterrent and treatment effects of correctional practices, probation and parole, and an examination of various experiments in institutional and community based corrections.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course examines topics and perspectives on human-animal relationships (HARE) from multiple disciplines within the humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences.  We will explore the complex relationships between humans and other animals, past and present, including the socially constructed meanings of animals that shape animal/human interactions and relations within institutions and social, cultural, geographic and interactional contexts.  We will consider many types of relationships between human and nonhuman animals, both beneficial and detrimental, as well as the trends that are impacting the future of animal/human relations on the planet.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The course provides a critical examination of various media, especially film, video and television, from a sociological point of view. It serves as an introduction to various theories of mass media and to current research on the effects of mass media on the human self in particular and society as a whole.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course explores various historical and contemporary social movements and protest movements.  In each of these explorations key social and cultural dynamics are emphasized, including mass communication and persuasion, strategies and tactics for acquiring power, the emergence of collective goals, and the politics of social change.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course explores the processes and patterns by which power is negotiated and contested by political authorities and social movements.  The course emphasizes the roles that factors such as class, race, and gender play in how politics unfold at the state level and how individuals organize collectively to influence politics.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course examines how groups of people create alternative and novel forms of cultural expressions (popular culture), and how such expressions eventually are filtered through media, either oral, electronic or print.  It also considers how the meaning of popular cultural expressions both influence and are influenced by broader and institutionalized societal arrangements.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Monday Night Football, Game 7, Buzzer Beater, Stoppage Time, and Underdog stories are all part of society's sports vernacular.  But what do they mean for the individuals who prepare, participate, and spectate sport?  These are just several of the key questions this course aims to explore.  Sociology is the study of the social world and how society is constructed, reconstructed, and maintained through patterns of social relationships and social interactions in everyday life.  This course is built on the idea that sport is a reflection of society and provides an excellent window and platform to investigate how such processes happen.  This course takes a cross-cultural, historical, and transnational perspective to the study of the intertwining of sport, culture, and politics to provide a well-rounded understanding and introduction to the sociology of sport.  Several themes this course explores are the different social and cultural meanings attached to sport, varying patterns in sport participation, the global sports economy, and labor in the sport industry.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of the process of death from a social psychological perspective.  Topics will include the dying process as an interactional event, how survivors cope with loss, the life chances of people to live an extended life before dying, and how death serves as a symbol and metaphor for lived experience.  The course will also focus on death as it has an impact on survivors and how survivors learn from the experience of another's death.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of social psychological theories of the social self and how social selves are represented in various American films from the 1940s to the present.  The course will combine lectures on concepts and processes associated with the presentation of the social self in everyday life with passages from films that provide detail about concepts and processes.  Film displays will include processes of impression management and characterizations of social types - ranging from violent/impulsive to rational/strategic selves.  Further, lectures and film passages will address the various portrayals of human relationships that involve self-display and self-disclosure.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the role of the wedding not only as a ceremonial rite of passage, but also as a multi-billion dollar industry in American society.  Beginning with a historical overview of the role of the wedding in society, the course will address issues ranging from the emotion work of wedding work, bride power, the role of the wedding industry in a culture of divorce and the impact of the illegal diamond trade on war torn nations in Africa.  A global comparison of wedding rituals will be included in the analysis, as well as a cross ritual/industry comparison of the funeral industry.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20223 or permission of instructor.  Theoretical and empirical literature on deviance and social control, showing how deviation arises from social interaction.  Specific attention to forms of deviance including substance abuse, sexual deviance and violent behavior.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20223 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of corporate and governmental deviance addressed from a sociological perspective.  Emphasis is placed on the nature, extent, and costs of corporate and governmental deviance, with special attention on the social, structural, and organizational forces which give rise to such deviance.  For example, we will examine the Ford Pinto case, Cold War Human Radiation Experiments, political corruption, Enron, and many other recent and historical cases.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course introduces students to the impact of technology and social media in everyday life on dimensions of society such as the individual, groups, social processes, social institutions, and social structures.  Particular emphasis is on understanding the impact of social media in areas such as politics, economics, revolutions, work, family, and everyday social interactions.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The sociological and social psychological examination of the impact of aging on the individuals and on society.  Focus is on defining demography of aging, the problems, public perceptions and stereotypes, concepts and theoretical perspectives on aging, age norms and constraints, adjustment patterns and changing lifestyles in old age, retirement, death and dying, exploitation, and politics of aging.  Societal issues that confront older Americans are discussed.  The course is primarily concerned with aging in the United States.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOCI 20213.  This course deals with the social context in which individuals experience food, with particular emphasis on how food influences, and is influenced by society.  From the rituals of dinner and Americans' obsession with diet food, to global food production regimes, the role of food in patterns of social life, social institutions, social inequality and social change will be explored.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Discusses the intersection of food and justice.  Investigates injustices generated by the current U.S. food system and by global agribusiness against farm workers in Mexico and the U.S. against residents of underprivileged communities in U.S. cities.  Explores possible solutions to these injustices, including fair trade, urban agriculture, food banks, and food policy councils.  Students will design an experiential, service learning group project in conjunction with TCU and community partners.  (offered as ANTH or SOCI credit)

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This class explores three iconic social types that emerged most visibly in the post WWII era-beatniks, hippies, and punks.  Drawing upon classic sociological concepts and ideas - including the stranger in society, alienation, anomie, the small social group, rebellion, deviance, and social status - the course depicts the melodramatic changes in discourse, appearance, and emotional touch during the decades of the 1950's, 1960's, and 1970's.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOCI 20213, or SOCI 20223 or permission of instructor. An introduction to understanding the role of religion in society and to sociological methods for the study of religion. The course will introduce theories and research pertaining to types of religious experience, conversion and commitment, denominationalism, secularization and fundamentalism. Class, gender, race and ethnicity will also be addressed as they influence religion in society.  (Offered as RELI or SOCI credit.)
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213, or SOCI 20223 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course introduces students to the sociology of aging and the life course.  Topics such as age as a social construct, shifting definitions of life stages, the sociological study of biographies, population aging, social theories of aging, inequality during later life, and other issues pertinent to older adults are explored.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20233 or any course approved for the minor/emphasis in Women's Studies.  Critical examination of new ideas, data and theories about the roles of men and women in contemporary society. Focus is on a sociological analysis of gender stratification in our society.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or 20233 or any course approved for the minor/emphasis in Women's Studies

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course introduces students to the myriad ways in which sexual desire and sexual activity are structured by social relations and to the ways that sexuality, sexual practices, and sexual identities vary in time and space.  We will also consider how those social relations and sexual identities influence ethical judgment regarding various sexual practices and attitudes.  Social science and philosophical theories of sexuality will be considered and cross-cultural and historical accounts of sexual practices will be reviewed.  (Offered as PHIL 30343 or SOCI 30773 credit)

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course will examine the body, not through the lens of the physical or biological sciences, but as the product of complex social arrangements and processes.  We will study the body as the container and expression of the self, as the object of social control, and as the repository of shifting race, gender, and sexual categories.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of the major aspects of victimology. Topics include the historical role of victims, the nature of victimization in modern America, the victimization experience, legal aspects of victimization, victimization and the political process, solutions to victimization, and the future of victims' rights and victimology.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOCI 20213 or permission of instructor. An exploration of the foundations of sociological theory through the works of the classical theorists, e.g. Marx, Durkheim, and Weber, assessing the impact of their work on current sociological thinking and practice and on society itself. Attention will be paid to the intellectual heritage of the thinkers, their historical context and their biographical selves.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course explores how politics is shaped by gender and, in turn, how gender shapes politics from an international and comparative perspective.  The course will address how states have institutionalized gendered rights and responsibilities, such as maternity and paternity leave, and how social movements have emerged to advocate for new policies related to gender and sexuality.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of the relationship between legal institutions and social processes. Topics include the nature of law, historical evolution of legal systems, creation and organization of law in modern societies, social functions of law, and limits of law as an instrument of social control.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: CRJU 20413, SOCI 20213 or PSYC 10213 or equivalent. An examination of the social psychological theories and research relevant for understanding criminal behavior.  Topics include societal and victim responses to crime.
courses.prerequisites: CRJU 20413, SOCI 20213 or PSYC 10213 or equivalent

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This is a seminar-style, site-based course taught in London as part of Leadership London, a TCU summer study abroad program.  The city of London will provide the backdrop for studying social and cultural influences on leadership.  Case studies are used to critically examine the nature and practice of leadership and explore the ways that social and cultural contexts shape leader-follower relationships.  The course is designed to illuminate diverse perspectives on leadership and provide a knowledge base for evaluating and making informed judgments about leadership.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An overview of Japanese history and major cultural traditions.  Japanese society will be looked at from its origins through the Tokugawa period and onto modern Japan.  Religious traditions and cultural perspectives will be highlighted.  Additionally, the place of modern Japan in the global community will be examined.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An overview of the functioning of the Japanese policing, court, and correctional systems.  In addition, both Japanese street crime and organized crime will be examined with special emphasis on the organization and history of the Japanese Yakuza.  Further, the course will examine the realities of a myriad of social problems in Japanese society both as individual issues and as causes/effects of criminality.  These topics include but are not limited to issues of poverty, urbanization, drug use and family structure stresses.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An overview of Japan's perspectives on and efforts toward sustainability in relation to the environment and economic/technological growth.  Issues of mass transportation, energy production, green architecture, and farming/fishing will be addressed.  In addition the place of sustainability as a philosophical dovetail to Japanese religious and cultural traditions will be highlighted.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This study abroad course provides a sociological perspective of Sweden, Denmark, and Norway along with a specific emphasis on sustainable practices within the cities of Stockholm, Copenhagen, and Oslo.  The course includes 4 days of online preparation, and 2 weeks of travel and lectures within Scandinavia.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The course keys on the consequences of being labeled mentally ill (or of being stigmatized), the societal response to mental illness, and the experience of managing particular conditions, especially depression, identity disorders, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).  The course also focuses on the sociohistorical and socially constructed concepts and contexts associated with defining mental illness and becoming mentally ill.  The course relies on a lecture-discussion format, making use of several concepts that have become linked to mental illness in general and the specific aforementioned conditions.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course examines, from a social psychological perspective, the complex and dialectical relationship between meeting expectations (conformity) and defying expectations (rebellion) in regard to decisive activity.  A social psychological perspective emphasizes the decisions people make in provocative settings, or contexts that involve moments of truth.  In this vein, conformity appears in opposition to rebellion .  However, conformity can, and often does, imply some form of rebellion just as rebellion implies some form of conformity.  Both conformity and rebellion can become problematic, or linked to existential decisions to either act against habit, judgement, and moral standpoints.  Rebellion can be seen as an unwanted occurrence that threatens our preferred styles of life, requiring resolution through conformity; conformity can become seen as an impediment to a free society which, in order to salvage a sense of free choice, requires some form of rebellion.  Examination of the complex relationship between conformity and rebellion can sharpen our focus when considering, specifically, in what kind of society we wish to live.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Offered in the fall semester only.  A supervised research experience culminating in the writing of a research paper typically based on the subject matter studied in SOCI 30003:  Honors Seminar in Sociological Ideas. The course is offered on a directed study basis and this must be arranged prior to the semester enrolled.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An exploration of the social and cultural aspects of the relationship between humans and other animal species, with particular focus on (1) examining the place, meaning and treatment of animals across historical periods, cultures, and social contexts, (2) understanding a range of debates and controversies regarding the ways animals are used by humans, and (3) exploring how humans construct social meanings and identities for themselves and others through animals.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The course provides analysis of contributions of sociologists to theory and research in basic decision making, including examination of theories of conformity, social influence and symbolic interaction.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOCI 20213 or consent of the instructor.  Courses taught under this designation focus on research design, perspectives and/or methods useful for conducting applied social research.  Topics may vary from semester to semester in accordance with the changing interests of students and instructors.  (May be repeated up to 6 hours under different topic offerings.)
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213 or consent of the instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: The course provides a critical examination of how the media responds to and helps create images of a particular social problem, drug abuse.  It serves as an introduction to theories and research pertaining to drug abuse, alcoholism, and to distinctions between justifications for the legality of some drugs and the illegality of others.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: An examination of the causes, treatment, and prevention of delinquency, with particular focus on the relationships between juveniles, clinics, and the court, and the philosophical, historical, and traditional foundations of juvenile law.  NOTE:  Credit not awarded for both CRJU/SOCI 40463 and CRJU 40473.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOCI 20213, or 20223, or permission of instructor. Critique of the changing structure and functioning of the institution of medicine in America and the continuing inter- and intra-institutional contention for authority. Focus on current issues, problems, and trends such as litigation, governmental financing and regulation, corporate entry into medical care, sexism in medicine, and alternative medicines and practitioners.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213, or 20223, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. (1-3 semester hours)
courses.prerequisites: Permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisites: 2.5 GPA in the Sociology major, completion of 12 credit hours of SOCI courses and approval of instructor.  This course provides sociology majors with in-class instruction and supervised placement opportunities in public or private organizations. Students gain practical knowledge and work-related experiences that connect sociological training with potential career paths. Student activities mayinvolve work both at TCU and/or outside of TCU (but inside the state of Texas), including field work, service learning,  practicums, internships, or volunteer positions

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisites:  SOCI 20213, SOCI 20223, or WGST 20003.  Human sexuality is often thought of as a realm of experience outside of or unmarked by society. In contrast, this course introduces students to the myriad ways in which sexual desire and sexual activity are structured by social relations, and to the ways that sexuality, sexual practices, and sexual identities vary in time and space. Social science, feminist, and queer theories of sexuality will be considered, and cross-cultural and historical accounts of sexual practices will be reviewed. Topics include the historical emergence and elaboration of forms of sexual desire ("sexualities" and categories of sexual orientation), sexual identities, sexual subcultures and communities, sexual scripts, sex panics and the political manipulation of sexuality, the institutional nature of heterosexuality, and the ways in which sexuality as social institution and identity intersects with other major hierarchies of power, privilege, and inequality: race, socio-economic status, and gender.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213, SOCI 20223, or WGST 20003

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOCI 20213, 20223, or permission of instructor. Examination of the current status of inequality in contemporary American society in terms of the distribution of power, prestige, and wealth. Critical assessments of economic, status, racial sexual, and political inequality.  Focus on such dimensions as the impact of inequality on personal life chances, crime, and social mobility, the feasibility of equality in our society, the programs and policies to reduce inequality and their political and societal ramifications.
courses.prerequisites: SOCI 20213, 20223, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: A sociological examination of work, particularly in a contemporary U.S. context.  Focus is on how work has changed over time, how government and corporate policies impact the workplace, and how and what types of work inequalities persist.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.description: Prerequisite: permission of instructor, and graduate standing.  Supervised reading, research and completion of a substantial paper.  May be taken for credit ranging from 1-6 semester hours and may be taken more than once.
courses.prerequisites: permission of instructor, and graduate standing

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Prerequisite: Departmental permission.  Not applicable toward degree requirements for the B.S. in Computer Science.  Introduction to block structure language including scope rules, recursion, pointer variables, and control constructs.  Study of data structures including arrays, stacks, linked lists, trees, graphs, and files.  Examples are selected from operating systems, compilers, and systems programming.  A number of programming assignments in Pascal, C, or Ada will be made.
courses.prerequisites: Departmental permission

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Prerequisite: COSC 30403 or permission of instructor.  Introduction to object-oriented techniques including design methodologies and programming language support.  Survey of new languages and extensions to existing languages which provide support for encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism.
courses.prerequisites: COSC 30403 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: May be taken with SOEN 50104. An introduction to software engineering with emphasis on process models. The evolution of conceptual process models is traced from the earliest waterfall model through incremental development to present day process architectures. An overview is also given of techniques for systems analysis, software cost analysis, configuration management, quality assurance, and maintenance. Software economics, planning, and management are introduced.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Prerequisite: Knowledge of a high level programming language such as Pascal or C, and previous exposure to predicate logic.  Foundations of Artificial Intelligence; topics include logic, forward and backward chaining, state-space search, expert systems and automated reasoning.  Projects may utilize the Prolog, Lisp and Clips programming languages.
courses.prerequisites: Knowledge of a high level programming language such as Pascal or C, and previous exposure to predicate logic

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOEN 50143.  Ada is used as a vehicle to study modern software design and development techniques.  Special emphasis is placed on the use of abstraction, information hiding, and safe programming practices such as strong typing.  The unique features of Ada, such as packages, the use of generics, and tasking, are contrasted with much "smaller" languages such as C.  Proposed extensions to Ada are also examined in terms of the additional complexity and overhead that these changes incur relative to the added generality that is obtained.
courses.prerequisites: SOEN 50143

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Advanced topics of current interest in software engineering, such as User Interface Development, Object-Oriented Architecture, Networking and Distributed Systems, Software Environments, Expert Systems, etc. Students will study current literature. May be repeated for credit when topic changes.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: The principles and practices related to assurance of software quality through all life cycle development phases are studied. Metrics linked to productivity and software quality assurance requirements are studied, and their use in current software development processes is reviewed by examining samples of measurement practices at successful organizations.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: A study of the problems and legal issues involved in building safety-critical software systems, secure systems, and systems that require high reliability. Similarities and differences in these problem areas and procedures to deal with them are considered using current literature, case studies, etc.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: A comprehensive study of state-of-the-art techniques for requirements definition and design of software systems. Customer to contractor communication practices and specification standards are discussed. Structured analysis, PSL/PSA, and other formal methods of software requirements definition are studied. Functional decomposition, data flow, data structure, and object-oriented software design methodologies are studied. Emphasis is placed on comparing and contrasting these methodologies and on selecting a methodology appropriate to various software engineering problems. A course project provides hands-on experience with the use of Computer Aided Software Engineering CASE tools for software requirements definition and design.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: The concluding phases of the software lifecycle from implementation through customer support are covered. Procedural language programming and alternative methods of software generation are discussed. Formal and pragmatic methods of module testing, software integration testing, and system verification and validation are studied. Software maintenance topics are considered from the viewpoint of reducing the customer's total software lifecycle cost. The course project begun in SOEN 6113 is completed and demonstrated.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: A comprehensive study of process considerations in software systems development. Included are software project estimating, planning, monitoring and controlling mechanisms; leadership and team building strategies; quality assurance issues; configuration management; and maintenance considerations.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: The logical organization and functional behavior of computers are studied from the user's viewpoint. Fundamental principles in the design of the CPU, memory, and 1/0 devices of the traditional von Neu), and multiprocessing are addressed. Several existing multiprocessor systems are studied in detail. Substitute courses may be taken with permission of the chair or faculty advisor.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: The requirements analysis and design criteria of database systems are studied with emphasis on relational databases. Design issues, including the use of normalized forms to optimize relational databases, are discussed. Students make use of the industry standard interactive command language SQL. Impacts of the operational environment, quality control, security, human/system interface requirements, systems specification and design are investigated.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: This course is the first of a contiguous two-semester sequence which applies the techniques of modern software development to actual problem solutions. Group projects will be assigned, based in part on the student's professional background. The projects will require the development of operational software, emphasizing group development processes to accomplish feasibility analysis, costing, planning, requirements specifications and preliminary design of the assigned project.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Preliminary design of the project assigned in SOEN 70113 is reviewed and the detailed design is executed. A critical design review is performed and the implementation, testing, and documentation are completed as a group process. Acceptance testing is accomplished to ensure that the software satisfies the user specification requirements.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Students will study some element of current coursework or a related area with the chosen faculty advisor and will prepare a technical paper of publishable quality. The paper will be submitted to an appropriate journal for publication.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Selected when enrolling only for non-thesis examination or preparation for the examination.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Departmental permission is required.

courses.subject: SOEN
courses.description: Prerequisites: 70980 and admission to candidacy.
courses.prerequisites: 70980 and admission to candidacy

courses.subject: SOSC
courses.description: Social Science Transfer Credit, carrying TCUCC Social Science credit.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Transfer work.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Intro Social Work - Transfer Credit, carrying TCUCC SSC.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Students will learn about the social work profession, critically explore a variety of social problems, and review how social workers seek to address these problems. Topics include the history of social work, careers in social work, and advocacy efforts at the micro, mezzo, and macro levels of social work practice.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor, and enrollment in the Honors College.  An examination of an issue affecting the social work profession or a field or method of social work practice determined in consultation with an instructor. This course is offered on a directed study basis and this must be arranged prior to the semester enrolled.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor, and enrollment in the Honors College

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites:  SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  This course will look in-depth into application of child development theory in working with children of all ages across multiple settings and cultures.  Students will learn skills to work with children, parents and families.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  Students will learn about various forms of addiction, including the biological, psychological, and social factors that contribute to addiction, and the anticipated outcomes of addiction. This course emphasizes how social workers can address addiction through intervention across the micro, mezzo, and macro levels of practice.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This course examines theories and methods of social work intervention, with an emphasis on intervening with justice-involved clients. Students will develop skills that can be applied to practice with individuals, families, and groups in both community-based and institutional criminal justice settings. This course is most relevant for students who are Criminal Justice and Social Work majors and minors (course may be offered as CRJU or SOWO credit).

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisite: SOWO 10833. This course focuses on the social welfare system as it affects children in American society. This class focuses on the historical development of the system, the existing structure and the processes through which present policies have been established, child welfare agencies and programs, principles and policies on which children's services are based, social and legislative issues relevant to children and children's programs, and
specific techniques for working with children. This course also examines the nature and dynamics of child abuse and neglect in American society, the assessment and identification of abuse and neglect, as well as direct practice and intervention within the child welfare system.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Corequisites: NTDT 30993.  Students will study and compare complex issues that affect social and economic justice in Spain and the US, with a focus on civic responsibility for addressing global problems.  Students will gain an understanding of global problems such as poverty, homelessness, hunger, and health care, and how each country responds to them through policy and service delivery.  Students will participate in service learning activities to see firsthand how services are delivered to vulnerable populations in both countries.  The course is open to all majors and is taken concurrently with NTDT 30993.  Fluency in Spanish is NOT required.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOWO 10833 or permission of the instructor. Students will examine selected cultures in an international setting. The course emphasizes the social and cultural factors associated with human service delivery systems in the destination country. Open to all majors; usually taught in summer abroad program.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of the instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  This course introduces theories and skills related to macro social work practice and focuses on issues related to spatial justice and critical competence. It utilizes an interprofessional approach by examining the various macro systems that impact communities and ways in which community organizations utilize community assets to create
large-scale change. This course introduces and utilizes skills related to community organizing, community development, community and organizational assessments and evaluations, and community research.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisite: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  Human Behavior in the Social Environment I examines global issues and trends that provide context to prenatal through adolescent development. Students acquire knowledge of policies, practices, and interventions in various countries and develop an understanding of the impact of geographical, cultural and political factors on developmental outcomes of individuals, especially children and adolescents. Although the course is part of a 2-course sequence, it can be taken independently. It can also be
taken concurrently, before, or after SOWO 30853.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor. The course focuses on physical, cognitive and socioemotional development during emerging to late adulthood. It critically examines the effects of trauma, identity characteristics, group membership and marginalization on healthy aging. Although the course is part of a 2-course sequence, it can be taken independently, It can also be taken concurrently, before, or after SOWO 30843.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  This course focuses on understanding particular historical and current social policies and issues affecting the development of social welfare services and the relationships between basic societal values and social welfare services. The course will also examine the impact policy has on social and economic justice, diverse groups, and  marginalized populations.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor. Students will learn how to conduct an initial client interview. Skill areas include informed consent, gathering data, motivation and rapport, assessment, goal setting, and referrals and resources. Knowledge, values, and skills taught in this course align with the generalist practice approach.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This course represents credit earned through a semester study abroad experience with an institution or program with which Texas Christian University has an official agreement to accept credit.  The site and specific content will be identified on the official transcript. Courses appearing on a student's official transcript have been included in the student's grade point average.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Offered fall only. A supervised research experience culminating in the writing of a research paper typically based on the subject matter studied in SOWO 30003. The course is offered on a directed study basis and this must be arranged prior to the semester enrolled.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833, or permission of instructor.  This course focuses on the use of animal assistance as a therapeutic intervention in working with clients across varied settings. Students will learn the theory and practice of animal assistance, and research findings related to the effectiveness of animal assistance. The course includes a mixture of lecture, visits to therapeutic sites, and guest speakers who share their insight from the field.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This course provides an overview of contemporary issues in a variety of settings, designed to empower future social work practitioners with the conceptual frameworks and knowledge base necessary for effective intervention.  The focus of the course will be on models of service delivery to address the impact of intimate partner violence across the lifespan including children exposed to IPV, dating violence, and older women.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  This course is designed to provide the student with an overview of social work practice in schools. Students will examine the history of school social work, state and federal education laws, educational issues and policies, conceptual frameworks (such as the ecological
approach) and service delivery models. Evidence-based programs, interventions and practices will be highlighted; in particular, those that optimize the potential for growth and learning, especially among at-risk youth. The course is intended to develop awareness and understanding of the unique role that the school social worker has and how it influences the lives of children, families, school staff,
schools, and communities.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites:  SOWO 10833 or by instructor permit,  This course comprehensively explores the social problem of homelessness in the United States.  It examines how homelessness in the United States has changed over time, risk factors for homelessness, and individual, familial, and societal consequences of unresolved homelessness.  The course will also evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of social policies and practice interventions meant to address homelessness.  The course will provide an immersive experience involving meetings with key stakeholders and subject experts as well as visits to local homeless assistance agencies.  The class will also visit different communities in Texas to understand how manifestations of and responses to homelessness differ between communities.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or by instructor permit,  This course comprehensively explores the social problem of homelessness in the United States

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  SOWO 10833. Social work in sport is an emerging specialization within the greater field of social work. There are many issues relevant to social workers that are distinctly related to sports and athletes both nationally and globally. Topics of interest to social workers and other disciplines alike include 
public concern for player welfare and conduct, mental health among athletes, coaching and 
organizational neglect (i.e., issues internal to U.S. gymnastics, Penn State, etc.), equal pay, and 
advocacy for ownership and representation among exploited athletes. This course aims to provide a 
foundation for professionals interested in social work and social justice through sport, 
recreation, and play settings to assist clients, programs, and organization in their efforts to 
support equity, global health, and psychological well-being for individuals and athletes.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Designed for students who undertake readings or projects in social work in consultation with an instructor.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor. Provides students the opportunity to explore interdisciplinary approaches to working with older adults, their families, and the larger community.  Involves a required service learning component in which students will develop skills, attitudes, and knowledge that will assist them in learning to value and promote healthy aging and quality of life with older adults.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Topics of current interest in social work. Possibilities include Crisis Intervention, Suicide, Discrimination, Play Therapy, Intervention Techniques, AIDS, and Social Work with Special Client Populations.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  This course focuses on aspects of the law relevant to social work practice.  Students will apply legal frameworks to social work practice with families, offenders, people with mental illness, and consumer protection. Students will also learn what constitutes negligence and malpractice by social workers, the laws and ethics of confidentiality,
and how to effectively collaborate as a social worker with the legal system.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor.  This course
is an introduction to aging and/or an overview of the field of gerontology. Major concepts, theories and principles of gerontology will be introduced. Students will explore ageism, current demographic trends in our society, and old age as a stage of lifespan development, health and healthcare concerns of older persons, issues of work, retirement, housing and economics, family relationships and social support, quality of life, and political issues of an aging society.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor. The course examines losses that elicit grief responses and explores ways the mourner finds meaning in life after a significant loss. We will look at a individual, family, and community level factors that can impact the grief experience of individuals and families. This course prepares students to work with clients on grief and loss.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites:  SOWO 10833 and 30863.  This course will focus on mental and behavioral health issues and their implications for the profession of social work.  We will study a) various careers in the social work profession that intersect with mental and behavioral health services, b) theories and frameworks for mental and behavioral health, c) issues of diversity, inequality, and stigma, and d) mental and behavioral health issues for specific populations.  This course is not meant to be an in-depth clinical overview of specific diagnoses, nor will it cover advanced clinical techniques.  Nevertheless, this course will encourage students to think critically about mental and behavioral health, and implications of these topics for their future professional practice.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833 and 30863

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This course will cover factors that cause and contribute to developmental disabilities (DD) such as Down syndrome and autism, development trajectories of individuals with DD (from birth to old age), contextual influences (family, community, school) on wellbeing of individuals with DD, and policy and programs designed to support persons with DD.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: MATH 10043 and SOWO 10833, or permission of instructor.  Students will learn the scientific method and how to conduct evidence-based practice. Students will learn how to find, read, and assess research studies found in academic articles and apply what they learn to social work practice. Knowledge, values, and skills taught in this course align with the generalist practice approach.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 10043 and SOWO 10833, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  SOWO 30833, 30883 and minimum 2.25 TCU GPA; minimum 2.5 GPA in social work; program approval through the junior evaluation process; concurrent enrollment in SOWO 40813.  The field seminar course provides the opportunity to integrate the knowledge, values, and skills learned in the classroom with what you will do in the internship setting. This is where you begin to work
in the world of social work practice and is a bridge to becoming a professional social worker.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 30833, 30883 and minimum 2

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites:  SOWO 40823 with a grade of C or better; minimum 2.25 TCU GPA; minimum 2.5 GPA in social work; program approval through the junior evaluation process.  Field seminar II continues the opportunity to integrate the knowledge, values, and skills learned in the classroom with what you will do in the internship setting. It is also where you begin the transition from student to professional
social worker and where you prepare to graduate.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 40823 with a grade of C or better; minimum 2

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 30833, 30883 and 2.25 TCU GPA; 2.5 GPA in social work; faculty approval; concurrent enrollment in SOWO 40813 and SOWO 40823.  In this class, you will have a supervised field internship within a social work agency. Students will have the opportunity to apply their social work knowledge and skills within a generalist social work setting. The student will be responsible for completing 240 hours (approximately 16 hours for 15 weeks) within the placement. There are additional fees associated with this course.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOWO 10883 or permission of instructor.   Students will develop group leadership skills and gain an understanding of the dynamic group process. Students will learn from course content, group leader skills trainings, and in-class demonstration groups.  Knowledge, values, and skills taught in this course align with the generalist practice approach, and are applicable to various group work formats.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10883 or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 10833, or permission of instructor.  Students who take this course will learn to think critically about diversity. This course helps students distinguish between myths and realities related to cultural, ethnic, gender, sexual orientation, age, and ability differences. The course stresses experiential content and learning, and applies to both American and global contexts.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 10833, or permission of instructor

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description:
Prerequisites: SOWO 40883 with a grade of C or better; 2.25 TCU GPA; 2.5 GPA in social work; faculty approval; concurrent enrollment in SOWO 40833.  Field Education II is a continuation in the same field placement, allowing students the opportunity to extend and deepen, under professional guidance, the development
of practice knowledge and skills with clients. The student will spend 16 hours per week for 15 weeks in an assigned agency for a total of 240 hours. There are additional fees associated with this course.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 40883 with a grade of C or better; 2

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Students will learn about the social work profession, critically explore a variety of social problems, and review how social workers seek to address these problems. Topics include the history of social work, issues faced by marginalized groups with an emphasis on gender and sexism, careers in social work, and advocacy efforts at the micro, mezzo, and macro levels of social work practice.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Students will learn the scientific method and how to conduct evidence based practice. Students will learn how to find, read, and assess research studies found in academic articles and apply what they learn to social work practice. Knowledge, values, and skills taught in this course align with the generalist practice approach.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Students will learn to think critically about diversity. This course helps students distinguish between myths and realities related to cultural, ethnic, gender, sexual orientation, age, and ability differences. The course stresses experiential content and learning, and applies to both American and global contexts.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This course introduces theories and skills related to macro social work practice and focuses on issues related to spatial justice and critical competence. It utilizes an interprofessional approach by examining the various macro systems that impact communities and ways in which community organizations utilize community assets to create large-scale change. This course introduces and utilizes skills related to community organizing, community development, community and organizational assessments and evaluations, and community and organizational research.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This course focuses on physical, cognitive, and socioemotional dimensions of development from prenatal stage into adolescence. Through developmental theories and research, the course examines the effects of trauma, identity characteristics, group membership, and marginalization on children's developmental outcomes. Special emphasis is placed how the environment influences outcomes such as trauma, violence, healthcare access, and policies that specifically affect women and girls.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: The course focuses on physical, cognitive and socioemotional development during emerging to late adulthood. It critically examines the effects of trauma, identity characteristics, group membership and marginalization on healthy aging. Although the course is part of a two-course sequence, it can be taken independently. It can also be taken concurrently, before, or after SOWO 61843.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This course covers the historical development of social policies and the impact of these policies on various people groups, particularly within the U.S. context. Students will engage fundamental knowledge and skills related to policy analysis and social welfare issues as well as methods for working toward policy change.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Students will learn how to conduct an initial client interview. Skill areas include informed consent, gathering data, motivation and rapport, assessment, goal setting, and referrals and resources. Knowledge, values, and skills taught in this course align with the generalist practice approach.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: This foundation-level field seminar course provides students the opportunity to integrate knowledge, values, and skills learned in the classroom with what they will do in the internship setting. In this course, students begin to work in the field of social work practice; the course is a bridge to becoming a professional social worker. Through experiences in the student's agency and field seminar, students gain a sense of professional identity and apply social work knowledge and skills in human service delivery. There are additional fees associated with this course. A grade of B or better is required in SOWO 61883 to continue to SOWO 61893.

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: Grade of B or better in SOWO 61883. This foundation-level field seminar course is a continuation of SOWO 61883. In this course, students continue opportunities to integrate knowledge, values, and skills learned in the classroom with what they will do in the internship setting. There are additional fees associated with this course.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of B or better in SOWO 61883

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission.  This course is designed for students who undertake readings or projects in social work in consultation with an instructor.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission. Through this course, students will examine the various theories and methods of the treatment of addictions. Students will learn to engage, assess, intervene, and evaluate interventions among various client populations that are affected by addictions.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission.  This course introduces social work students to the law and legal systems, legal issues for professional social workers, and legal issues pertaining to social work practice, with a specific focus on how laws and legal systems impact children and families.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 61893.  This course builds on the content from previous practice classes and students learn advanced practice content that encompasses knowledge and skills to work with families as client groups.  This content includes engaging clients in an appropriate working relationship, identifying issues, problems, needs, resources, and assets; collecting and assessing information; and planning for service delivery.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 61893

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: SOWO 61823 or equivalent credit.  This course explores questions of contemporary global poverty, economic and social inequality, social injustice, and environmental degradation.  The course perspective includes Western and non-western interpretations of poverty, inequality, and social injustice to ensure that students evaluate a diverse set of theories and understandings about these social problems.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 61823 or equivalent credit

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisites: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission.  This course is constructed around current interests in social work.  Possible course topics would evolve as current events and evolutions in the profession make these important for further investigation.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission. This course exposes students to some of the varied practice settings that exist under the umbrella of medical social work. It builds on generalist practice classes and interprofessional education to provide students with an opportunity to enrich their social work knowledge and skills inside a healthcare context.
courses.prerequisites: Admittance to the MSW Program or by instructor permission

courses.subject: SOWO
courses.description: Prerequisite: SOWO 61863.  Students will study and compare complex issues that affect social and economic justice through social policy and social service delivery.  Students will gain an understanding of global problems such as poverty, homelessness, hunger, and health care, and how each country responds through policy and service delivery.
courses.prerequisites: SOWO 61863

courses.subject: SOWO
